data.name: Zurich Tonhalle
data.abstract: For those with an interest in classical music, the Zurich Tonhalle is hard to ignore. One of the world's most acoustically perfect concert halls, it is home to Switzerland's oldest symphony orchestra – an internationally renowned ensemble.
data.description:
Founded in 1868, the Tonhalle Orchestra is the oldest symphony orchestra in Switzerland. With the opening of the Zurich Tonhalle in 1895, the orchestra was given a hall whose acoustics are rated among the best in the world. The magnificent hall was inaugurated in the presence of Johannes Brahms. Top-class conductors have helped to turn the Tonhalle Orchestra into what it is today, with a series of CD recordings of works by Richard Strauss, Robert Schumann and Gustav Mahler that document its rise to prominence. The seminal complete recording of Beethoven's symphonies in the late 1990s won the “German Record Critics' Award” and caused a sensation in the music world. 

In recent years, the Zurich Tonhalle Orchestra has emerged as one of Europe's leading ensembles. Its highly motivated musicians present approximately 100 public concerts each season, with about 50 different programmes. Since the 2019/2020 season, the Estonian conductor Paavo Järvi has been Music Director of the orchestra, whose family concerts bring joy to young listeners. Designed for twenty-somethings, tonhalleLATE is a series of exceptional events combining a classical concert with a party including electronic music.

Although the Tonhalle is home to the Tonhalle Orchestra, the grand hall is also used by many other orchestras keen to demonstrate their skill in this wonderful setting with its magnificent acoustics.

data.name: Zurich walking tours
data.description: The volunteer guides take their guests on a free stroll through the city and show them the town they live in. Every free walking tour is personal and different: architects take guests through the Langstrasse area or Zurich-West, bankers prefer the financial centre, and students choose the university.

data.name: Zürichhorn and the Chinese Garden
data.abstract: In the green parks around the lower basin of the lake, there’s always something going on in the summer months. Inline skaters, water sports enthusiasts, jewellery sellers and street artists all gather here to create a colourful scene. Anyone looking for peace and quiet will be able to escape the hustle and bustle on the Zürichhorn at the end of the lakeside promenade, in the wonderful Chinese Garden.
data.description:
On the Zürichhorn and in other areas by the lake in Zurich-Seefeld, you’ll find a range of popular wild bathing spots. From here, large rocks or small pebble beaches will lead you down to Lake Zurich. Shady trees and areas with lots of space on which to play or relax, such as the Blatterwiese, invite you to stop and linger awhile.

Following on from the “Expo 64” in Lausanne, the “Heureka” sculpture by Jean Tinguely was given a new home on the Zürichhorn, ultimately becoming a striking new part of the lakeside promenade.

The Chinese Garden was a gift from the city’s Chinese sister city of Kunming in thanks for the technical and scientific support provided for the expansion of the drinking water supply and urban drainage in Kunming. It is classed as a temple garden and is one of the highest-ranking gardens outside of China.

data.name: Zurich milieu tour
data.abstract: The district around Zurich’s Langstrasse has a turbulent past. Today, its authenticity, multicultural diversity and cosmopolitan outlook are what makes it special.
data.description:
The two districts nestled on the left and right sides of Langstrasse are popular among trendsetters from around the world, and are an insider's tip for shoppers. Over the last few years, many artists, architects, designers, fashion designers and innovative gastronomes have established themselves in the city’s former red light district, which was also once predominantly a refuge for poor, young families. The result is an interesting mix of the old and the new, design and abandonment, exotic and early Zurich influences, combined with historical and modern elements, which are reflected in the shops and cuisine you’ll find in both districts. 
Content of the tour:
 * Find out more about the district’s eventful past
 * Marvel at the multicultural atmosphere
 * Discover the cosmopolitan trendy district/Langstrasse


Click here for more information and dates: www.zuerich.com [https://www.zuerich.com/en/visit/culture/im-viadukt#internal]

data.name: Zurich Airport observation deck
data.abstract: Experience fascinating insights and views of everything going on at the airport.
data.description:
Observation Deck B with public guided tours and bus tours
Observation Deck B offers excitement and fascination for airport fans both young and old. Experience aviation up close and watch flight operations and the pilots in the cockpit as they prepare for take-off. Observation Deck B also has a “mini-airport”, a play area for children. They can enjoy slides and see-saws as well as a small aircraft and a control tower.

Would you like something to eat or drink on Observation Deck B? The Aviolino restaurant offers hot and cold snacks as well as refreshing beverages.

Would you like to explore Zurich Airport as a solo guest, in a small group or as a family by bus or on foot? You can book a bus tour or walking tour of the airport in advance or drop by the tour desk at Observation Deck B on the day.

During the tour, make sure to stop off at the unique runway intersection and experience a take-off up close. Or get to know the processes of the airport on a walking tour and take a look behind the scenes.

More information [https://www.flughafen-zuerich.ch/en/passengers/experience/experiences/observation-deck-b]

data.name: Zurich Airport – Duty Free
data.abstract: Take advantage of our attractive duty-free offers while on your travels!
data.description:
At Zurich Duty Free, passengers can choose from a wide range of high-quality and exclusive products and market innovations prior to departure or when returning from abroad. Compared to normal retail prices, you can save up to 20% on duty-free goods such as perfumes and cosmetics and up to 50% on spirits and tobacco products. All goods sold here are original branded products. While 700ml bottles are common for spirits in normal retail, duty-free offers mainly involve litre bottles.

The range on sale at Zurich Duty Free goes far beyond the usual branded products. In addition to local specialties such as chocolate or spirits, you will also find special sizes and special packaging as well as “Airport Exclusive” products that are exclusively available to duty-exempt air passengers, some of which are specially manufactured for these sales outlets by brand partners. Exclusive and local cosmetics brands such as Rausch and Swiss Prestige Cosmetics or Zurich Gin from Turicum are just a few examples from the wide range of products available at Zurich Duty Free.

Enjoy services such as hand massages or a make-up refresher from MAC, Estée Lauder, Bobbi Brown and many other brands. Specialist sales staff are on hand to provide expert advice in the area of skincare, and you can also test products.

In addition to the actual duty-free shops, which are exempt from VAT, there are a large number of other shops in the transit area at Zurich Airport that offer a wide range of products: from souvenirs to clothes, jewellery to watches, leather goods and accessories, right through to entertainment electronics and handmade chocolates. These shops offer you selected items that are not available in normal stores in this format, quality and packaging.

data.name: Zürich Opera House
data.abstract: With just 1,100 seats, Zurich’s is the smallest of the great international opera houses, and offers an exceptionally intimate experience of top performances.
data.description: Its programme is highly varied, with 17 new productions and 26 revivals a year. Popular pieces, famous singers as well as regular premieres, children's operas and ballet are all included in the varied repertoire. Stars such as Cecilia Bartoli, Renée Fleming and Placido Domingo enjoy appearing here time and again, as do celebrated conductors including Nikolaus Harnoncourt, Christoph von Dohnányi and Carlo Rizzi.

data.name: Zurich museum on rails
data.abstract: A train ride with an over 100 years old steam train! The "Zürcher Museumsbahn" offers this unique event which will make the stay in and around Zurich even more rememberable.
data.description:
An event in the atmosphere of the Belle Epoque. The journey starts in the station Zurich-Wiedikon – just one stop away from Zurich Main Station - with destination Sihlwald. This trip can be combined with a light lunch in our dining car and is suited for old and young, families or groups.


More information under www.museumsbahn.ch [http://www.museumsbahn.ch ]

data.name: Zurich Airport
data.abstract: With Airport Shopping and the Circle, duty-free shopping, the viewing terrace, a park and walking routes, Zurich Airport is an exciting place for a day out.
data.description:
FOR VISITORS
More than 100 shops and restaurants in the public area of Zurich Airport are open daily from morning to night.

Shopping
Airport Shopping and the Circle offer a selection of shops for everything from groceries, books and electronics to gifts and souvenirs.
More information [https://www.flughafen-zuerich.ch/en/passengers/shopping-and-enjoy/shops/all-shops]

Food & Drink
The restaurants at Zurich Airport also offer the full range for large and small appetites. Whether it's an unforgettable dinner at the Rooftop Restaurant Sablier, a refreshment of Sapori d'Italia on the go, a sparkling cocktail at the upperdeck restaurant or a stopover at Foodland – Zurich Airport offers an exciting gastronomic concept with its popular and well-known restaurants.
More information [https://www.flughafen-zuerich.ch/en/passengers/shopping-and-enjoy/eat-and-drink/all-food-and-drink]

Services
The services at Zurich Airport are available from morning to night. Find out more about the wide range of services offered by Zurich Airport and benefit from the countless advantages.
By booking "ZRH Comfort", you benefit from access to the priority lane at the security check and can choose a snack and drink from a wide range of options. Our partners Pret A Manger, Starbucks and NZZ Café are easily accessible at every dock and offer you the opportunity to enjoy your catering where it suits you best.
[https://www.flughafen-zuerich.ch/en/passengers/practical/services/services-for-travellers]More information [https://www.flughafen-zuerich.ch/en/passengers/practical/services/services-for-travellers]


Nature & Aviation
In the midst of the urban business world in the Circle, the airport park invites you to linger. Beautifully designed seating is available for guests to use free of charge and is ideal for a break in nature. In addition, you can enjoy a breathtaking view of the airport and the surrounding area from the sky platform in the park. If you want to experience the airport up close, you can visit the observation terrace. Aviation enthusiasts can take a close look at aircraft of all kinds during the various guided tours and round trips.
More information [https://www.flughafen-zuerich.ch/en/passengers/experience/experiences/park']



FOR TRAVELLERS
Zurich Airport offers you an unforgettable stay and a relaxing journey. Find out everything you need to know about your flight and keep track of everything. It is particularly worthwhile to plan enough time – there are numerous shops and exciting gastronomy concepts to discover in the passenger area.

Arrival and departure
Many roads lead to the airport – and away from it. Travelling has never been more convenient and the choice of modes of transport has never been more diverse. In the website navigation under the heading "Flying" you will find all relevant information about your arrival and departure as well as your selected airline or destination.
More information [https://www.flughafen-zuerich.ch/en/passengers]

Services for travellers
The services at Zurich Airport are available from morning to night. Find out more about the wide range of services offered by Zurich Airport and benefit from the countless advantages.
By booking "ZRH Comfort", you benefit from access to the priority lane at the security check and can choose a snack and drink from a wide range of options. Our partners Pret A Manger, Starbucks and NZZ Café are easily accessible at every dock and offer you the opportunity to enjoy your catering where it suits you best.
More information [https://www.flughafen-zuerich.ch/en/passengers/practical/services/services-for-travellers]

Food & Drink
Even if you travel early in the morning or late at night, food is provided. The shops in the passenger area usually open one hour before the first flight and close when the last flight is called.
More information [https://www.flughafen-zuerich.ch/en/passengers/shopping-and-enjoy/eat-and-drink/all-food-and-drink]

Shopping
Duty-free shopping at Zurich Duty Free or would you rather visit another shop? After the security check at Zurich Airport, a wide variety of brands can also be found – from Swiss originals to world-famous brands.
More information [https://www.flughafen-zuerich.ch/en/passengers/shopping-and-enjoy/shops/all-shops]

Hotels at Zurich
Airport Barely landed and already at the hotel or do you have an early flight from Zurich? Directly at Zurich Airport and in the immediate vicinity you will find various accommodation options. Many advantages and a stylish overnight stay are guaranteed, our recommendation – the Hyatt Regency, the Hyatt Place and the Radisson Blu.
More information [https://www.flughafen-zuerich.ch/en/passengers/practical/services/hotels-and-convention]

data.name: Discover Zurich by e-bike
data.abstract: Zürich is best discovered away from the well-known tourist attractions. On a guided or solo bike tour by e-bike, take the path less traveled through Zurich's outlying suburbs for a day that is memorable for all the right reasons.
data.description: Let the high-performance EGO Movement e-bikes take you through a variety of outlying suburbs, as well as nature areas close to the city. Authentic city life can really be this special. No distance is too far, and the cycle paths are well signposted. On these guided tours, you'll see picturesque towns and villages and learn about exciting and surprising stories.

data.name: Discover Zurich’s open-air bars
data.abstract: How better to spend a balmy summer’s evening than relaxing with a cool drink at one of Zurich’s atmospheric open-air bars?
data.description:
The city’s many open-air bars are a popular meeting place for locals and tourists alike. Whether in the heart of the urban quarter, on the banks of the river or with magnificent views over Lake Zurich and the Alps, there is an open-air bar for everyone! As well as the open-air bars, the river and lake lidos in Zurich are a wonderful place to relax. As dusk falls, some of these lidos are transformed into trendy lakeside bars, with events such as concerts, readings and fascinating film screenings.

More information [https://www.zuerich.com/en/visit/open-air-bars]

data.name: The Zürich Trolley Experience
data.abstract: Experience the exclusive city tour by letting the unique “Classic Trolley” taking you on your discovery tour of Zurich.
data.description: You will see and learn much more about the city than on a conventional tour. Because the audio-taped commentary is available in 8 languages, you will have a far more interesting and comprehensive report solely in the language of your choice.

data.name: Lake Zurich Cruises
data.abstract: Enjoying unforgettable moments on a boat cruise or aboard one of Lake Zurich Navigation company’s Dream Boats.
data.description:
During all seasons and on all parts of the lake as well as the river Limmat, Lake Zurich Navigation offers various scheduled boat cruises daily (between 1.5h and 4h). Passengers can relax on well-maintained steamboats or motor vessels as well as Limmat boats while enjoying the lovely landscapes that roll past. 

For a very special experience, passengers may treat themselves to one of the Lake Zurich Navigation company’s boat cruises on various Dream Boats. Among these are the Fondue Cruise, the Steamboat Dinner or the Late Riser’s Brunch (Breakfast Boat). Whether party person, epicurean or families, there is a suitable Dream Boat for everyone.FACTS


Route: e.g. Zürich – Rapperswil – Zürich Distance: length of the lake to Rapperswil 28 km, total length of the lake including upper lake 42 km Duration: 1 h 30 min, 3 h or 4 h EXCURSION TIPS
 * Knie’s Kinderzoo (children’s zoo) Rapperswil
 * Lakeside promenade Walenstadt
 * Rapperswil, the “City of Roses” on the shores of Lake Zurich with picturesque old town and four rose gardens
 * Uetliberg – Zurich’s local mountain
 * Chocolate factory Lindt & Sprüngli

FOOD & BEVERAGES
Catering services available in the boat restaurants.TIMETABLE
All connections here [https://www.zsg.ch/en/timetable-prices/timetable-assistant/round-trips-scheduled-cruises]TICKET
This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]

RESERVATIONS
No seat reservation required – free seating.

data.name: Criminal Zurich
data.abstract: Gripping storytelling of crimes at their original locations. We hike to crime scenes to recount true stories. True Crime, told live and in context. We know how to bring history to life.
data.description:
Learn about the dark side of Zurich: the Zurich epoch of Bonny and Clyde, the German Autumn, which had offshoots running all the way to Switzerland, the huge loss of confidence in the authorities in the 1960s, the first big case of bullying, with unimaginable consequences, cash flows in Zurich, which stream rather resourcefully outside the intended channels, and acts of aggression before Zurich became “Europe's most gay friendly city”.

ENVIRONMENT: A walking tour of the city of Zurich! It doesn’t get any more resource-efficient and emission-free than this. We serve regional delicacies and drinks are enjoyed from reusable cups. Everything is transported to the final destination by bike.

SOCIETY: We have stories to tell of innovations in the world of work (whistleblowing, mobbing), of the often long road to humane conflict resolution, of civil courage among authorities, police officers and people in prison, as well as pioneering spirit in social, judicial and healthcare sectors that have made Zurich a model city. There is just so much to learn from our tours: “I now find myself walking through the city in a completely different way” is a frequent phrase that gives us great pleasure. Again and again, historical facts flow into these stories.

ECONOMY: As members of the sponsoring committee of the Martin Foundation Erlenbach, we support the foundation’s work programmes (gastronomy, agriculture, biodiversity on the right bank of Lake Zurich) by purchasing pastries and wines for the aperitifs. We offer our tours for NGOs, cantonal or municipal institutions, schools from all over Switzerland and parishes at a reduced rate.

data.name: The Zurich Trolley Experience - city tour
data.abstract: Enjoy the sights of Zurich aboard the nostalgic "Classic Trolley".
data.description: This approximately 2-hour tour will show you the business and financial centre, the Bahnhofstrasse, the most important museums, the historical Limmatquai, the Grossmünster Church, St. Peter's Church with the largest clock face in Europe, the Fraumünster Church with its famous Chagall windows, residential areas, the university quarter, and vantage points of Zurich. Headphones are supplied so that you can listen to detailed commentary in the language of your choice (German, French, Italian, English, Spanish, Portuguese, Russian and Japanese). In summer you can enjoy the city tour in the open air – there is outdoor seating at the rear of the vehicle.

data.name: Helferei Zurich
data.abstract: The unassuming office building at 13 Kirchgasse belies the importance of the work that was accomplished within its walls. Here is the "Helferei", the office where Huldrych Zwingli studied and wrote the sermons that forever altered Zürich and Switzerland.
data.description: The small room that served as Zwingli's office is located upstairs, remarkably unaltered since the great Swiss Reformer occupied it. The rough, wood-paneled walls and sloping wooden floor appear just as they did in the 16th century, as do the thick glass windows looking out on the garden out back. The entire Helferei is still owned by the church. Downstairs the building houses a bookstore, a fair trade shop, meeting rooms and a chapel dating from 1856. Zwingli's office is still used by the Grossmünster's ministers, who draw inspiration from the space as they prepare their sermons.

data.name: Architecture in Zurich Tour
data.abstract: From romanesque and historicism through to modern architecture – downtown Zurich boasts a diverse range of architectural styles.
data.description:
This walking tour takes around two hours and introduces architecture fans to significant buildings in Zurich´s inner city. Between the majestic State Museum and Sechseläuten square, you will be guided past monumental constructions like the main train station, both universities, as well as numerous guild houses and religious buildings.

Buildings designed by renowned architects such as Max Bill, Gustav Gull and Gottfried Semper played a key role in the development of the city. This tour explains and showcases a variety of architectural styles from romanesque to historicism and right up until the present day.

data.name: Swiss Casino Zürich
data.abstract: Zürich’s casino, a member of the Swiss Casinos group, is the largest in Switzerland (3,000 square metres).
data.description:
Here on 3,000 square metres, there is plenty to keep gamblers happy as they try their luck 365 days a year on 400 slot machines and 26 gaming tables. Take time out to relax at the bar and in the atmospheric lounge with adjoining stage. 

Access is open to persons aged 18 and over with a valid identity card.

data.name: Walking Tour Zürich
data.abstract: The narrow, cobbled streets of Zürich's Old City were once home to many key figures in the Swiss Reformation. Their former residences and businesses are not open to the public, but most bear German historical markers. An easy walking tour encompasses them all.
data.description:
The Zähringerplatz in front of the Prediger Church incorporates a memorial to Christopher Froschauer; across the street stands the Froschauer family's 16th-century print house. Froschauer printed many of Zwingli's texts; in 1535 the printer published the first English Bible in Europe, the same Zürich Bibles that traveled with the Pilgrims to the New World. Follow Predigergasse to 5 Neumarkt, the former house of Konrad Grebel who, along with Felix Manz, founded Anabaptism. Walk along Neumarkt and south on Münstergasse to the Zwingliplatz, across from the Grossmünster, where Zwingli's successor Heinrich Bullinger lived in 1536. Successive generations of Grossmünster ministers lived there up until 1833. 

Within view of the Zwingliplatz at the corner of Neustadtgasse and Kirchgasse is the Haus zur Sul, the residence of Zwingli himself from 1522-25. If you follow Neustadtgasse south to 8 Trittligasse, you'll find "Zum Friesenberg", the home of Zwingli's widow and children from 1533-39. Follow Trittligasse west to the Limmat Riverbank. Beside the Wasserkirche stands the Zwingli Monument, depicting a rather stern-looking Reformer with his Bible and a sword. 

Cross the Limmat River by way of the Rathausbrücke. Head north along Schipfe until you arrive at the water-level marker where, in 1527, Felix Manz was executed by drowning for preaching Anabaptist theology.

data.name: Running in Zurich
data.abstract: On a city break but can’t do without your daily run? Or do you need to quickly clear your head after a meeting?
data.description:
Zurich is embedded in unspoiled nature, and as a small, sophisticated boutique metropolis, it offers amateur and professional athletes the perfect environment and the ideal terrain for training. The city on the water can be explored on a leisurely walk. 
 * Sightseeing tour 3km (lake basin and sights)
 * Zurich-West tour 5km (trendy neighbourhood Zurich-West).
 * Nature tour 10km (through the forest on Adlisberg)
 * Fitness trails (various fitness trails in Zurich)
 * Green marathon (different distances to choose from through and around the city, up to 42km)

More information [https://www.zuerich.com/en/visit/jogging-in-and-around-zurich]

data.name: Reformation in Zurich
data.abstract: 1519 – the year that changed Zurich. Ulrich Zwingli became lay priest at Zurich’s Grossmünster church, putting Zurich at the heart of the Reformation. He also paved the way for a social welfare system, the core of which remains unchanged to this day.
data.description:
Zurich didn’t have a Luther – we had a Zwingli! This historical tour provides you with comprehensive information and insights about how the Reformation came about in Zurich. We stroll past the majestic facades of the most important churches in downtown Zurich, visit commemorative plaques and monuments, and discuss the key stages in the work of reformer Ulrich Zwingli. Countless stops along our route make it clear that his endeavors were certainly no walk in the park. 

His disputes with the city and his calls for change are brought to life through various anecdotes and facts that were of vital importance for the success of the Reformation in Zurich.GOOD TO KNOW

 * Find out everything about the Reformation in Zurich
 * See evidence of how Ulrich Zwingli transformed Zurich
 * Learn about the foundation of the social welfare system

data.name: Hürlimannbad & Spa Zurich
data.abstract: At the Hürlimannbad & Spa Zurich, you bathe in century-old vaults that offer peace and relaxation.
data.description:
he central bathing area consists of a large, open stainless steel pool with invigorating massage jets, bubble loungers, massage and bubble rings. 

Other highlights include the emerald bath with underwater music and an exciting light show, a steam bath, a course bath and a rain shower. On the roof, the infinity pool offers a spectacular panoramic view over Zurich. The rooms - with many playful elements and details - are reminiscent of the former brewery. In the Roman-Irish spa ritual, the body is warmed, cleansed, relaxed and cooled down again in 10 successive stations - a source of soothing relaxation, health and vitality. 

In between, the bistro invites you to relax, rest and enjoy. You will find an always fresh selection of various hot and cold delicacies as well as exquisite drinks.

data.name: Voyage Culinaire Zurich
data.abstract: Enjoy a culinary experience consisting of team spirit, fun and sightseeing!
data.description: This culinary event is composed of a guided tour through Zurich and gastronomic team activities revolving around the topics of food and drink. Enjoy a 3-course menu in 1-2 different venues and a wine presentation of the wines you have selected for dinner.

data.name: Wilderness Park Zürich Langenberg
data.abstract: Visitors can observe 19 native and formerly native animals like deer, bear, lynx, wolf, wildcat, marmot, elk, wild boar, and the Przewalski horse on 80 hectares.
data.description:
The animals live in a spacious and natural environment and are therefore not always visible everywhere. However this makes encounters with animals fascinating and memorable. Adventure worlds intensify man’s encounter with the animal world.

A restaurant, children's playgrounds and various fire pits also invite you to take a breather.

data.name: Christmas in Zurich
data.abstract: Christmas markets, Advent concerts and fairytale trams: Zurich is simply magical at Christmas time. The whole city is bathed in warm light, the scent of cinnamon and mulled wine fills the air and Christmas carols can be heard everywhere. Many small shops offer the opportunity for extensive shopping. And of course there are also various Christmas markets.
data.description:
Zurich shines in every corner at Christmas time. Bahnhofstrasse shines with "Lucy", the special Christmas lights. Christmas lights shine in the Old Town and in many other places, bathing Switzerland's largest city in a very special light.

At Zurich's oldest Christmas market in Niederdorf or the popular Christkindlimarkt at the main railway station, locals and visitors alike come together to browse the stalls for rarities. At the "Wienachtsdorf" on Sechseläutenplatz, against the backdrop of the opera house, you feel like you're at home with St Nicholas. Countless enchanting market stalls with local products and many other attractions make guests big and small dream.

Children are delighted by the enchanting fairytale tram. The scent of cinnamon, chestnuts, punch and mulled wine is everywhere. And you should enjoy a raclette or fondue while strolling through the city centre. 

If you still haven't found the right gift, there are three Sunday sales and a night shopping event. And of course a large selection of Christmas markets.

More information:Christmas in Zurich [http://www.zuerich.com/en/visit/christmas-in-zurich]
[http://stadt-zuerich.ch ]

data.name: Steamboats on Lake Zurich
data.abstract: Steamboats operate scheduled services on eight of Switzerland's lakes today. Thanks to donations, the “Stadt Zürich” and “Stadt Rapperswil” have also been saved from the scrapyard. The two paddle steamers were renovated between 2003 and May 2006, and are now in use almost every day.
data.description:
In July 1835, the first iron steamboat on the European continent, the “Minerva”, went into service on Lake Zurich. To keep pace with passenger demand at the start of the last century, two large paddle steamers were then ordered: the sister vessels “Stadt Zürich” (built in 1909) and “Stadt Rapperswil” (built in 1914). Together with the “Helvetia” (built in 1875, the largest paddle steamer on Lake Zurich), the three boats formed the backbone of the Zurich fleet for many decades. 

Today, the Lake Zurich fleet comprises 17 boats: 15 motor vessels including three Limmat boats and the two remaining paddle steamers. The “Helvetia” left service in 1958, having covered a total of 200,000km. In March 2007, the 700-passenger ship "Panta Rhei" joined the fleet.

data.name: Cult restaurants in Zurich
data.abstract: Sniffing out good food in Zurich: The city’s foodie scene has been shaped by a number of well-known restaurants over the decades.
data.description:
Along with seeing the most important sights, no city break is complete without sampling the best local food. Every visitor to Zurich should visit at least one of the following restaurants!

 * Hiltl: Opened back in 1898, the first vegetarian restaurant in the whole of Europe now enjoys cult status.
 * Kronenhalle: Exquisite cuisine served against a backdrop of original works of art by Picasso, Giacometti and Chagall.
 * Oepfelchammer: Hearty Swiss food served in Zurich’s oldest wine bar.
 * Sternen Grill: The city’s best sausages served with the strongest mustard – street food Zurich style!
 * Zeughauskeller: The weapons in this former armoury now hang on the wall for decorative purposes only.

More information on these and other recommended restaurants can be found on the Zurich Tourism [https://www.zuerich.com/en/visit/zurichs-cult-restaurants] website.

data.name: Artistic stroll through Zurich
data.abstract: Public art shapes Zurich’s urban landscape and culture. In Zurich, there are around 1,300 public works of art that you can gaze at in wonder.
data.description:
On a short stroll through Zurich, art enthusiasts, city explorers and both amateur and professional photographers alike can discover and admire all manner of works of art, sculptures and art installations.

Click here for more information and dates: www.zuerich.com [https://www.zuerich.com/en/visit/art-in-public-places]

data.name: Park Hyatt Hotel Zurich by Meili + Peter
data.abstract: The 5-star Park Hyatt Zurich is located in the heart of Zurich, in the financial and business district between Lake Zurich and the Old Town. This modern building was designed by Zurich architects Meili + Peter and Zeno Vogel.
data.description: The building combines ultra-modern building technology with the latest comfort amenities. For this reason you will be greeted in the entrance area by a RUNTAL RX, all guest rooms and suites are equipped with RUNTAL bathroom radiators and even in the kitchen the easily cleanable RUNTAL ARTEPLANO has been installed to meet the special hygienic requirements.

data.name: Victorinox Flagship Store, Zurich
data.abstract: The store opened in October 2014 to celebrate Victorinox’s 130th birthday.
data.description:
It is located in the heat of the vibrant city of Zurich. Covering 180 square metres, this Victorinox store is among the largest there is, and there is plenty to discover.

One of the highlights is the huge pocket knife globe at the entrance. It consists of over 15,824 small red pocket knives arranged into a sphere to represent the globe. Sharp-eyed observers will spot one small, white pocket knife – this represents the Victorinox head office in Ibach-Schwyz.

As with all Victorinox stores, a variety of personalisation options are available. A visit is always worthwhile!

data.name: Urban bees on Zurichs rooftops
data.abstract: Participants encounter first-hand the bees of urban apiary Wabe3 on a roof in Zurich. At this event they can sense the life of honeybees, taste the honey from the city and round it up with a the wonderful view of the city.
data.description: Wabe3 is a young and innovative Zurich apiary. Their bee colonies are placed on unused flat roofs that enjoy spectacular views of the city of Zurich. In this way they are making a contribution to nature’s diversity in the city while providing the public with a glimpse into the fascinating world of beekeeping. Experienced beekeepers explain the fascinating life of bees in a colony and demonstrate some of the key basics directly at the hive. The event’s highlight is tasting honey straight from the honeycomb.

data.name: Fondue Tram in Zurich
data.abstract: Dip your fondue fork into the melted cheese as the oldtimer tram leisurely circles through Zurich on its tour.
data.description:
A ride on the Fondue Tram is an exquisite experience. As the lights of Zurich's inner city glide by outside, the staff will present you with a delightful cheese fondue.

The vintage tram embarks from Bellevue and meanders past all of Zurich's most charming locales, including the picturesque Limmatquai with its historic guild houses, through Paradeplatz, and over the Quaibrücke, spanning the River Limmat and Lake Zurich.

More Informationen: Fondue Tram Zurich [http://extrafahrten.vbz.ch/en/eating-with-all-the-senses-the-vbz-gourmet-line/fondue-tram/]

data.name: Rope & Adventure Park Zürich-Kloten
data.abstract: Canton Zurich’s first rope park offers fun and thrills in the forest for everyone above age 4.
data.description:
Over 10 courses with five skill levels. Visitors can test their skill, balance, coordination, courage, strength and endurance at lofty heights. 
Everyone will find what he seeks in the rope park. 

The guides are multilingual, so each visitor can be seriously attended to and instructed. Fitness, sturdy shoes, and out-door clothes suitable for all weather are preconditions for a visit to the rope park. 

Over 130 obstacles – distributed over all age groups – are ready to be climbed. Plus a 1-km cable car, ready for use. This is pure action adventure!INFORMATION

data.name: Shop at well-known Zurich labels
data.abstract: Zurich is a fashion hotspot and home to a multitude of well-known fashion labels. From Freitag bags and Tiger-Fink slippers to Viu glasses, Zurich is the birthplace of numerous fashion labels.
data.description:
Stroll through the city’s narrow streets, gaze through the windows of wide-ranging boutiques and treat yourself to something in your favourite store – shopping in Zurich is an unforgettable experience. Fans of fashion, trends and design should head to Freitag, Fabric Frontline with its shelves of precious silks, EnSoie, Qwstion, Soeder and Stefi Talman, all true artisan gems. Don’t miss out on a visit to these wonderful boutiques!

More information [https://www.zuerich.com/en/visit/zurich-labels]

data.name: Round trip around Lake Zurich
data.description: Captain Rolf Egg takes his guests on a boat trip around Lake Zurich. The exclusive boat can fit up to ten passengers and is a chance to see the city from the water. On the journey, the Captain will share interesting stories about how the city has changed since the 19th century. The trip takes around one hour, but can be extended on request. The boat launches at Utoquai 6 or the Bürkliplatz.

data.name: Senses City Tour – explore Zurich
data.abstract: A treat for all the senses. This sensory tour offers a striking combination of diverse experiences and fascinating discoveries about Zurich.
data.description: Zurich is the perfect city for gourmets and explorers. Classic Swiss cuisine, world-famous chocolate and traditional music are just some of the sensory stimuli that await. This sensory tour brings together a great variety of experiences that inspire the eyes, ears, nose, tongue and spirit.

data.name: À Maurice Watch Workshop in Zurich
data.abstract: Maurice the watch-whisperer invites: There aren’t many people who know the souls of things, …and even fewer can make these souls perceptible and tangible to others. Maurice can. If you also desire to belong to this chosen group, then you have to come to Maurice. “à Maurice”, from Maurice de Mauriac, is a meeting place for people who want to feel and to experience the soul of mechanical watches.
data.description:
To find the souls of mechanical watches, you don’t necessarily have to open up them up. Instead, if you simply open yourself, then you can hear, touch, and feel this soul. Daniel Dreifuss and his sons are able to create this intimate atmosphere. In order to ensure that no one leaves without having acquired a profound knowledge “à Maurice”, the watchmaker, who day in and day out works on and together with the souls of the mechanical watches, is also present.

Friends of watches, families, employees, customers and everyone who wants to sharpen their awareness for the intangible values—those who avoid superficiality and desire to become more contemplative, more attentive—will love Maurice.

At the end of this journey there always lies a deeper, more profound realisation. And the same holds for Maurice that holds for whispering: It isn’t exactly clear why, but one’s view of things—and, of course, of mechanical watches—undergoes a change.

We eagerly await to share such moments with you.

“à Maurice” in greater detail:
à Maurice takes place in the creative surroundings of the atelier
à Maurice possesses an informal and intimate atmosphere à Maurice creates a sensory approach to mechanical watches 
à Maurice shows you how to make a mechanical watch stylistically and intrinsically your own unique timepiece
à Maurice conveys the soul of the mechanical watch
à Maurice imparts values such as beauty, quality and leisure Mindfulness, empathy and love
à Maurice is made up of Daniel Dreifuss, his sons Leonard and Massimo, and the watchmaker
à Maurice takes between 2 and 4 hours, according to what has been agreed upon.

data.name: Private group tours at ETH Zurich
data.description:
ETH Zurich offers various themed tours at the two locations in the centre and on the Hönggerberg. Visitors can take a look behind the scenes of one of the best scientific and technical universities in the world and discover amazing, eye-opening and curious things.

What makes the experience special?

Our guides speak Swiss German, German, English, French, Italian and Mandarin. The tours are basically free of charge (there is the possibility of a donation to the ETH Foundation).

What is the local/regional connection?

During the tours, visitors can rely on real experts: students and staff of ETH Zurich. They not only know the facts about their university, but can also give first-hand accounts of everyday life.

data.name: Foxtrail – fun in and around Zurich
data.abstract: The fox takes chasers on seven different trails across Zurich and Winterthur. The fox has made off between the lake and Hallenstadion, and chasers will need cunning, teamwork and urban speed to catch it.
data.description: The fox has laid its trails. Secret messages, hidden clues and many tricky and perplexing challenges show you the way from one stop to the next. You are out on the trail by yourself and never know what’s waiting in store for you – even people familiar with the region are bound to discover new things. The Foxtrail takes you through towns and countryside on foot and using various means of transport. The trails last between 1.5 and 4.5 hours. All you’ll need is good shoes and a mobile phone per group in case you need to call the hotline. Pricing depends on your age and the length of the trail. Simply book online through the website, print the starting instructions and enjoy solving the puzzles!

data.name: Food Tour – a guided walk through Zurich-West
data.abstract: Gourmets can discover the culinary aspects of Zurich on a guided walk through the trendy Zurich-West quarter.
data.description:
On the Zurich Food Tour, gourmets can explore Zurich-West – once an industrial district and now a trendy quarter – in a rather unusual way. Along with other food lovers, they visit on foot restaurants and bars that are particularly popular among the locals. The tour provides an insight into the eating and drinking culture of Zurich’s inhabitants and at the same time relates some interesting facts and figures about Zurich’s so-called “gastronomic revolution” or how the Zurich-West quarter came into being. 

Besides tasty appetizers made from vegetables, meat, fish or seafood, a selection of alcoholic beverages are served – including freshly brewed Zurich beer.

data.name: Segway city tour
data.abstract: This guided city tour combined with the fun of riding on a new environmentally-friendly electric Segway takes you on an exciting voyage of discovery through Zurich’s city centre.
data.description:
The tour includes short stops at such famous locations as Lake Zurich, Bahnhofstrasse, Münsterhof and Limmatquai. Beautiful districts and squares are explored, and comprehensive commentary is provided. 

The two-hour tour includes a driving lesson of approx. 20 minutes duration. Registration is required on the previous day at the latest. Tours may be cancelled due to poor weather conditions.

Minimum age: 18, category A1 driving license required. GOOD TO KNOW

 * Ride on a Segway 
 * Short stops at the most famous sights 
 * Tour guide included

data.name: Heureka by Jean Tinguely
data.abstract: The Heureka was created by Jean Tinguely for the Swiss National Exhibition in Lausanne and has been located at Zürichhorn in Zurich since 1967. This large kinetic sculpture made of iron bars, steel wheels, metal pipes, wooden wheels and various electric motors was Tinguely's first public work.
data.description: Tinguely's idle machines are recognised worldwide as an allegory about the consumer and industrial society. For Jean Tinguely, the machine stood for humour and poetry. The many plastic wheels symbolise both wisdom and madness in one. Jean Tinguely (d. 1991) was a contemporary Swiss painter and sculptor and follower of the French Nouveau Réalisme art movement. Its members had set themselves the goal of eroding the lofty status of fine art and of using new techniques and materials to integrate the reality of everyday life into art.

data.name: Fraumünster Church
data.abstract: Located on the west bank of the Limmat, the Fraumünster Church with its green steeple is one of Zurich's most prominent landmarks. Particularly renowned are the glass windows by Marc Chagall and Augusto Giacometti.
data.description:
The church was built from the middle of the 9th century on the opposite side of the river to the Grossmünster [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/grossmuenster/]. Today, many visitors are attracted by the five stained glass windows prepared by Marc Chagall in the 1960’s as well as by the the rosette in the south transept. Another significant glass window is "The Heavenly Paradise" (1945) by Augusto Giacometti, the uncle of the famous Swiss artist Alberto Giacometti, in the north transept. 

With 5793 pipes, the organ in the Fraumünster Church is the largest in the Canton of Zurich [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/zurich-region/]. A cycle of frescos by Paul Bodmer depicts the legend of the founding of the monastery and of the city's patron saints Felix and Regula.

data.name: Stadelhofen Train Station
data.abstract: The construction of the Stadelhofen Train Station in Zurich is the work of the famous Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava. Built in 1884, the late-classical station building had a concrete and steel platform roof added in the 1990’s.
data.description: An equally organic sculptural stair and bridge system serves as a pedestrian passage across the railway and up to a gangway providing passers-by with seating and a view. Particularly striking are the ornate hinged doors that close off the exits to the underground shopping area each night. Stadelhofen Station is not Calatrava’s only work in Zurich. He also designed the Alumni House and the Library of the Law Institute at the University of Zurich. After completing his degree in civil engineering at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in the 70's Calatrava opened his first architecture and engineering firm in Zurich in 1981.

data.name: Stand-Up Paddling City Tour
data.abstract: Explore the city of Zurich from a different perspective ‒ in the course of an active leisure pursuit of a very special kind!
data.description:
On this guided tour, you will discover some of Zurich’s history-steeped places of interest from the water – standing on a paddling board. Participants are introduced to the art of stand-up paddling and at the same time learn all kinds of interesting historical facts about the city of Zurich along its waterways.

More information [https://www.zuerich.com/en/visit/tours-excursions/sup-city-tour#internal]

data.name: Prime Tower
data.abstract: The Prime Tower is Zurich’s tallest building, a sparkling, glass-clad construction soaring 105.5 metres above the fashionable Zurich- West district.
data.description: This new landmark building in Zurich is located in a trendy part of the city that was once an industrial area. Head up to the Clouds restaurant on the 35th floor for drinks or dinner – and spectacular views over the city, lake and mountains.

data.name: Culture route
data.abstract: In the Zurich Region, the Alps remain discreetly in the distance. Centre stage is given to culture, history and all the attractions of city life.
data.description:
Here you’ll find everything from avant-garde theatre and medieval castles to seductive shopping, idyllic lakefronts and sensational cuisine – plus it’s all wonderfully easy to reach, whether you’re exploring by car or train.

Here you find detailed information on the route: PDF Culture route [/-/media/st/documents/gtos/grand%20tour%20gpx%20daten/103_15k_04_gtos_regionale_routen_zuerich_e.pdf] 
Hereafter, we present 10 suggestions for excursions along the tour.
TIPP 1: SCHIFFBAU
The Schiffbau was originally a ship factory; today it serves as a venue for theatre, jazz and innovative cuisine. The former industrial building is a protected monument; artfully modernised, it now houses three different theatre stages, the jazz club Moods, the fashionable LaSalle Restaurant and the NietturmBar – a stylish bar with floor-to-ceiling windows offering superb views of super-cool Zürich-West. TIPP 2: CABARET VOLTAIRE
100 years ago, in bourgeois, conservative Zurich of all places, a group of young iconoclasts formed the Dada art movement. Hugo Ball, Emmy Hennings, Tristan Tzara and others performed their sound poetry and simultaneous poetry in Cabaret Voltaire at Spiegelgasse 1 – just round the corner from where Lenin lived. Cabaret Voltaire is still open to the public, as a museum, theatre, shop and bar in one. TIPP 3: SECHSELÄUTENPLATZ
It’s hard to believe that this fine square in front of the opera house, right in the city centre, was recently a little-used patch of ground where the Knie circus pitched its tent once a year. Today, paved with elegant quartzite and featuring a bistro and playful fountains, the new city piazza has become a popular rendezvous with locals and visitors alike, a delightful spot to relax amidst the city bustle. TIPP 4: BRUNO WEBER SCULPTURE PARK
Step foot in Bruno Weber Park and you feel you have entered a fantasy world. Created by the eponymous artist on a hillside overlooking the Limmat valley, the leafy park combines exotic architecture with colourful concrete sculptures of giant imaginary creatures, and enchants visitors of all ages. The park is located in Spreitenbach near Zurich, and is easy to reach by car, bus or suburban train. TIPP 5: RIVER LIMMAT ART TRAIL
The Kulturweg Limmat (“Limmat Culture Trail”) links the pretty footpaths that run along both banks of the River Limmat below Wettingen Abbey, forming a scenic loop between the wooden bridges of Baden and Wettingen-Neuenhof. Along the way, walkers can admire 26 works by renowned Swiss artists. The route is clearly signposted and accessible year-round; there are information panels at the main access points. TIPP 6: CASTLE OF LAUFEN AT THE RHINE FALLS
The medieval castle of Laufen stands on a dramatic rocky outcrop high above the thundering Rhine Falls. The observation platform offers a thrilling close-up experience of Europe’s mightiest waterfall, while a glass panoramic lift promises a breathtaking view from on high. Inside the majestic castle, the Historama exhibition tells the intertwining story of the 1,000-year-old fortress and its waterfall. TIPP 7: MUSEUM OF FINE ARTS WINTERTHUR
The museum of fine arts in Winterthur, second-largest city of the Zurich Region, is one of the most important in Switzerland. Founded more than 100 years ago, the museum features a stylish extension by the architects Gigon and Guyer, added in 1995. The superb collection of international art from the 19th century through the classical modern period to the present day is a must for all art enthusiasts. TIPP 8: ENEA TREE MUSEUM
Enzo Enea is a celebrity among landscape designers. He has created gardens and parks for princes, sheikhs and pop stars all over the world. The public, too, can appreciate his art in Rapperswil-Jona, where Enea presents individual trees with his typical unfussy, almost Japanese elegance, as if in a museum. The overall effect is of a complete work of art that combines nature and culture with eloquent style. TIPP 9: UFENAU MONASTERY ISLAND
The island of Ufenau, near the towns of Freienbach and Pfäffikon on Lake Zurich, radiates a blissfully peaceful aura. This sacred spot has belonged to Einsiedeln monastery since AD 965, and is now a nature conservation area. Swimming and skimpy clothing are not allowed, but respectful visitors are welcome to explore the two idyllic churches – and are promised a warm reception at the island’s restaurant. TIPP 10: OLD TOWN OF ZUG
It would be hard to find a more idyllic location: Zug’s picturesque Old Town, with its cobbled streets and beautifully renovated medieval houses, stands right on the shore of Lake Zug. Already from afar, you recognise emblematic buildings such as the historic clock tower, town hall and church of St. Michael. The “Guggi” viewpoint offers a glorious vista taking in the Old Town, castle and defensive towers. INFORMATION

Careful planning is a prerequisite for an enjoyable tour. Please inform about the weather and road conditions beforehand at the local information point. According to the season and the weather conditions, the route might be closed or interrupted.

data.name: Longstreet Bar
data.abstract: As the name suggests, the Longstreet Bar is located right on Zurich’s amusement mile, the Langstrasse. Today, the restaurant is a popular meeting place for the locals. The interior as it was in the past, when girls danced here on the bars, has been retained.
data.description: It was not too long ago that the red-light district was very much at home here at the Longstreet and this is why the two-story bar is still dressed in red velvet today. It’s just the guests that are new now. The Longstreet regularly hosts bands and DJs. The large number of naked light bulbs hanging from the ceiling gives this bar a unique atmosphere.

data.name: St. Peter's Church
data.abstract: St. Peter's Church in Zurich is the only baroque church in the city. The clock on the tower is the largest in Europe and the dial has a diameter of 8.7 metres. There are also five bells in the tower dating back to 1880 with the largest weighing over 6,000 kg without clappers.
data.description: St. Peter's parish church is the oldest church in Zurich and dates to before the year 900. From the Middle Ages to 1911 the church tower was used as a fire lookout point. Rudolf Brun, the first mayor of Zurich, was buried in this church. The famous theologians Johann Caspar Lavater and Leo Jud both worked here. Of special note are the baptismal font of 1598 and the choir chairs with their armrests and rich carvings from the 15th century which originated in the suppressed convents of the city. Other attractions are the rich acanthus adornment with Bible verse over the pulpit, the crystal chandeliers modeled in the style of 1710 and the organ with 53 stops.

data.name: Mascotte
data.abstract: Clubbing at Zurich’s oldest nightclub.
data.description: This club with full lake views appeals to a wide clientele with its versatile programming that includes rock, black music, electronic, 60's to 80's, house and live concerts.

data.name: Rieter Park
data.abstract: The 70,000 m2 Rieterpark is Zurich's largest and most impressive landscaped garden and is set in the district of Zurich Enge near Lake Zurich.
data.description: The park and associated villa (now the Rietberg Museum) was created in 1855 and acquired in the late 19th century by the industrialist Rieter family from Winterthur. The city gained ownership in 1945. Some of the park’s beech trees date back to the original stock and are therefore more than 150 years old. On a clear day you can see as far as the Glarus Alps, which conveys the impression of an almost endless vista.

data.name: Historical Points
data.abstract: Home of the Swiss Reformation The story of Christianity in Zürich begins in the 4th century with the tale of the city’s patron saints, Felix and Regula. Threatened with execution due to their faith, the Roman siblings fled to Zürich, where they were captured and beheaded. It is said they picked up their heads after death and walked to the riverbank before collapsing. Their relics are now preserved in the Fraumünster, famous for its stained glass windows created by Marc Chagall.
data.description:
HIGHLIGHTS IN ZÜRICH
Religious sites [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/interests/excursions/religious-sites.html?start=26]
Overnight at a monestary [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/accommodation/other_types/extraordinary-hotels-in-switzerland/overnights-in-a-monastery.html]
Christmas Markets [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/event_calendar/event_results.cfm?f2=stxmas] 
BIRTH OF THE SWISS REFORMATION
Zürich made its most significant mark on Christian history in the early 16th century with Huldrych Zwingli and the Swiss Reformation. Zwingli spent his career working for church reforms, having grown disillusioned with the corruption and distortion prevalent in Rome. He publicly denounced the Catholic church’s reliance on saints as spiritual mediators. So engaged were the Zürchers of the early 16th century that they quickly embraced Zwingli’s Protestant doctrine, and in 1523 Zürich’s city council elected to become a Protestant city.

THE ANABAPTISTS
Among Zwingli’s closest followers were Conrad Grebel and Felix Manz. The Anabaptists, as they were called, pressed for separation of church and state, adult baptism, freedom from taxation and military conscription. Zwingli couldn’t agree to such radical measures, nor could the Zürich city council. After refusing either to conform or to leave Zürich, the Anabaptists experienced their first martyrdom in 1527 when Felix Manz was executed by drowning. But while Manz was dead, he had begun a movement that would last, spreading throughout Switzerland, Germany and the Netherlands, and giving root to the modern-day Mennonite and Amish communities in North America. Several Lake Zürich towns were founded by Anabaptist communities in exile, where they resided or worshiped in secrecy caves. A visit to the Anabaptist cave in Bäretswil is a powerful reminder of the lengths early believers took to worship as they saw fit.

LAKESIDE METROPOLIS 
A lakeside metropolis with views of the snow-covered Alps, Zürich offers a mix of unique activities waiting to be discovered. A shopping paradise with renowned international as well as unique local brands. Delicious culinary treats, over 50 museums and more than 100 galleries, a world clas((s Opera House and numerous events invite visitors to spend time here and to explore the well- preserved Old Town, which can look back on a 2,000-year history. 

THE INTERNATIONAL MUSEUM OF THE REFORMATION
This museum is a must-see for religious visitors that come to Geneva, Switzerland. It begins with an emphasis on the Bible and includes some of the oldest French and English Bibles. Unique objects, manuscripts, rare books, engravings and paintings illustrate the close ties of Geneva and John Calvin to the Reformation.
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/interests/excursions/religious-sites/musee-international-de-la-reforme-international-museum-of-the-reformation-genf.html]
OVERNIGHT IN A MONASTERY
Experience how it is to live in a monastery and overnight in one of the various abbeys and monasteries in Switzerland that offer simple accommodation. Some even offer their own mountain hut refuge to rent, like the convent of St.John in Muestair
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/accommodation/other_types/extraordinary-hotels-in-switzerland/overnights-in-a-monastery.html?all]
THE PILGRIMAGE WAY OF ST. JAMES ALONG SWITZERLAND’S BREATHTAKING MOUNTAIN SCENERY.
Walk or cycle on St. James' footsteps, following his ways through the breathtaking mountain scenery of Switzerland to Santiago de Compostela. Take your time to visit some of the traditional pilgrims' stations.
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/home/summervacations/excursion-summer/summer-mountain-tips/the-way-itself-is-the-goal.html]
CHRISTMAS MARKETS.
The Christmas season will soon be here again.. as well as the traditional Christmas markets in Switzerland. Montreux is home to the largest one, Bremgarten (Aargau) to one of the biggest ones in terms of vendors. The highest one can be visited on Mt. Pilatus. Others can be found in Huttwil (Bern), Zürich or Basel. 
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/service-updates/events.html?strubrik=2161]

data.name: Park im Grüene
data.abstract: The park “in the green” above Rüschlikon, which lies in picturesque position overlooking the lake of Zurich, is a genuine oasis for fun and relaxation.
data.description: The park is made up of extensive lawns and lovely playground on which children can let off steam while adults relax and enjoy doing sweet nothing as they admire the views from a lent deckchair. Water games and the diverse cultural program with puppet theatre, miniature trains, donkey rides and more excite both big and small. And a herb garden and self-service restaurant add to the makings of a perfect day!

data.name: Giacometti Frescoes ("Blüemlihalle")
data.abstract: The regional city headquarters of the Zurich police force houses a fresco by Augusto Giacometti (1877-1947) that is one of the most important works of art and architecture in the city of Zurich.
data.description:
When the former orphanage was converted into an administrative building in 1911, the basement was transformed into an entrance hall. In 1922, the city of Zurich launched a competition to decorate the entrance hall, aiming to brighten the gloomy space and to offer employment to the local artistic community. Augusto Giacometti won the competition hands down. His design in warm red and ochre tones was executed by the Giacometti himself and a number of other Zurich artists between 1922 and 1926, using the al fresco and al secco techniques. The paintings on the ceilings and vaulted roof consist of floral ornaments and geometric shapes, while the walls depict people at work: stone masons and carpenters represent handcrafts, while astronomers and magi represent science.



If you’d like to see the entrance hall to the police offices, known as the “Blüemlihalle” to the local populace, in all its glory, you can do so by presenting your ID at the entrance any day from 9 a.m. to 11 a.m. and from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m.Extensively restored in 2019, this is a work of art and architecture of national significance.

More information [https://www.zuerich.com/en/visit/attractions/giacometti-hall#internal]

data.name: El Lokal
data.abstract: Get stranded on the last island in the Sihl. That’s only possible at the El Lokal. This is the bar for real Zurich mariners and everyone else.
data.description: Enjoy a drink along with our tasty tapas in the relaxed atmosphere here at the El Lokal. We also serve delicious simple meals at lunchtimes. On weekends we host concerts by local and international bands. The locals often meet here to watch the football together.

data.name: Belvoir Park
data.abstract: This gem among the parks of Zurich was built in the middle of the beautiful park for a high-classicist style villa at the start of the 19th century. Today, this villa is home to the renowned Belvoirpark hotel management school and a restaurant.
data.description:
Belvoir Park is one of the region’s oldest landscape gardens. It is a special place of relaxation with expansive lawned areas, large pools, mature trees, and peaceful areas that are ideal for contemplation.

The fascination with this park is down to its location, which offers marvellous views of the city, lake and mountains, the artistic design of the terrain, as well as the backdrop of trees, which was rather unusual at the time.

Since 1985, visitors have also been able to enjoy an iris and daylily garden with over 120 species of flowers.

data.name: Schiffbau
data.abstract: Once used for shipbuilding, this former industrial building in the fashionable district of Zurich West is now an indispensable part of Zurich's cultural life.
data.description:
The Zurich Schauspielhaus uses this listed factory building, where ships were once manufactured, as a venue for productions and performances. Since 2000 it has run three theatrical stages here: the Schiffbauhalle, the Box and the Matchbox, all of which have achieved Europe-wide fame in their short lifetime. The Moods jazz club, the fashionable Restaurant LaSalle and the Nietturm Bar, accessible by lift and offering views across Zurich West, can be found in the same location. 

A visit to any of the Zurich Schauspielhaus venues is particularly rewarding each Monday, when all seats are available at half price.

data.name: Helsinki Club
data.abstract: The Helsinki Club in Zurich-West provides a platform for lesser-known musicians who have loads of talent and passion.
data.description: Small club with out-of-the-box musical offerings. Each concert here is unique and the admission prices affordable. Some of the best events include concerts organised by micromusic.net. Your visit to the Helsinki is sure to be full of surprises - thanks to our very diverse audiences and cosmopolitan atmosphere.

data.name: Freitag Flagship Store
data.abstract: Daniel and Markus Freitag developed their first messenger bag from a discarded tarpaulin in 1993. And today people all around the world are seen carrying the colorful bags with the unmistakable Friday Logo. The flagship store of piled freight containers attracts people from all over the world to the trendy Zurich Kreis 5 district.
data.description:
Unable to find a messenger bag that met their needs, the brothers Daniel and Markus chose to develop their own - the Friday bags that came into being in 1993. And since 23 years, the cult bags have been made from recycled truck tarpaulins, inner tubes of bicycles and car seat belts. Today the company employs 250 staff members, who are constantly developing and producing new products.

The flagship store in the trendy west of Zurich is in itself a cult. It consists of a stack of old freight containers that once made their way all over the world by sea. Fondly know as the "Bonsai Skyscraper" by the Friday brothers, it attracts customers from far and wide to Zurich - where they find themselves standing in front of a weird and wonderful construction before plunging into the Friday bag paradise.

data.name: Money, Money, Money
data.abstract: Get your money’s worth: this city tour packed full of facts explains how Zurich established itself as one today’s most important global financial hubs.
data.description:
This exciting tour through Zurich recounts the city’s long relationship with money, as highlighted by impressive and interesting facts: What does the silk industry have to do with banks? Who were the city’s money lenders and where did people first envisage a bold vision for the future? 

Answers to these and other intriguing questions will be explained during this leisurely stroll with a focus on historical economic aspects. The tour also includes a stop at Zurich’s highly symbolic wishing well. 

More information on the Financial and insurance sector [https://www.zuerich.com/en/visit/tours-excursions/history-of-money-in-zurich]

data.name: Irchel Park
data.abstract: Irchelpark is an ideal place to escape the hustle and bustle of city life and enjoy being surrounded by nature. Trees and bushes shield this relaxing retreat from the streets surrounding it. It’s not uncommon to cross paths with students of the University of Zurich’s Irchel Campus here. The institution’s buildings are set in an enchanting location in the upper part of the park.
data.description:
The park was built in the early 1980s and has since become a popular recreational area in the city of Zurich. With around 32 hectares, it is probably the largest of Switzerland’s younger parks and contrasts strongly with traditional city parks, which mostly follow clear lines.

In the lower part of the park, there is an artificial lake, which is home to many fish, birds and ducks, as well as open grasslands and an expansive play area. Nature has intentionally been left plenty of room to run wild.

The topography is livened up by large hills, creating a distinction between landscapes. In contrast to the technical buildings of the university, natural building materials and wild growth shape the park.

data.name: E-bike tour of public art
data.abstract: Zurich boasts a wealth of public art, with some 1,300 works of art around the city just waiting to be discovered. The easiest way to explore them is on an e-bike.
data.description:
The city of Zurich places great importance on public art. From the work of local graffiti artists to pieces by internationally renowned artists such as Fischli/Weiss, there is a myriad of artworks to be discovered throughout the city.

As some of the works are quite spread out geographically, this tour offers an easy way to explore them in a short space of time – just jump on your e-bike from EGO Movement and off you go!

In total, the bike tour lasts 2 hours and 15 minutes and is held every Saturday from May to October.

data.name: The Polybahn
data.abstract: An emblem of Zurich, the nostalgic Polybahn links the old town with one of the most beautiful viewing terraces high above the city.
data.description:
Since opening in 1889, the Polybahn has carried over two million passengers each year to the Polyterrasse between the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology and the University in just two and a half minutes. The route has not changed at all since it first came into service in 1889, and is a historic monument to late 19th century engineering.

Saved from closure at the last minute by a Swiss bank in 1976, the historic Polybahn was completely overhauled in 1996 and equipped with state-of-the-art technology, and in 2001 the upper station was repainted in its original Sienna red colour. Thanks to this complete overhaul, the Student Express, also affectionately known as the “Polybähnli”, will continue to transport future generations from Central to Zurich’s seats of learning and back.

How to get there: Walk from Zurich main station, crossing the Limmat to Central, then take the funicular to the Polyterrasse.


Altitude: 452 metres 
How to get there: 
Walk from Zurich main station, crossing the Limmat to Central, then take the funicular to the Polyterrasse 
Views: Across the city and Lake Zurich to the Glärnisch, Tödi, Clariden, the Albis chain and the Uetliberg 
Attractions: The funicular itself, which carries over two million people every year 
Food and drink: Speciality restaurants in nearby Niederdorf 
Accommodation: Zurich city (the Hotel Limmathof is right next to the lower station of the Polybahn) 
Winter: Runs all year round 
Special comments: No service on Sundays

data.name: Kaufleuten
data.abstract: The place to be for nightlife in Zurich.
data.description: This stylishly furnished club is probably the most famous night club in Zurich, attracting visitors and celebrities from around the world. Famous as well as infamous for its great parties.

data.name: A float by boat
data.abstract: Water is an ever-present feature of Zurich, which offers a wide range of activities for residents and visitors. The possibilities are endless. Experiencing Zurich from the water on one of the various boat trips is a really special treat.
data.description:
You can enjoy the view of the Old Town, for instance, from the Limmat boats named Felix, Regula and Turicum. Or you can enjoy an aperitif as you cruise into the sunset. Those who wish to spend longer on the water can treat themselves to a long cruise to Rapperswil and take part in a tour of the charming town of roses. 
In the evenings, 25 “dream boats” take to the lake: whether you’re into burgers, BBQs or hot stones, salsa, country music, hits from the 80s or schläger – there’s a themed boat to suit your taste.

More information [https://www.zuerich.com/en/visit/getting-around-in-zurich/by-boat]

data.name: Stories of the Old Town
data.abstract: Explore the historic centre of Zurich on this guided tour.
data.description:
The guided tour through the Old Town is a rewarding journey of discovery for both visitors and locals alike. Learn about Zurich's past and present through a selection of buildings, stories and anecdotes. You will be fascinated by the many witnesses from bygone days still in existence and which highlight the early international significance of the city. GOOD TO KNOW

 * Sightseeing in Zurich´s impressive old town 
 * Explore quaint alleyways and discover hidden gems 
 * Tour guide with extensive knowledge

data.name: Limmat river cruiser
data.abstract: The Limmat river cruiser takes you in comfort past the most beautiful sights of Zurich’s old town until the view of Lake Zurich opens up.
data.description:
Glide past guild houses, Zurich’s town hall, the Lindenhof fortress and the spires of the Grossmünster: a boat trip on the Limmat takes you from the National Museum up the Limmat to Lake Zurich and back again. The “Felix” and “Regula” cruisers are named after the patron saints of Zurich, while the “Turicum” bears the city’s Roman name. They all have glazed roofs so that passengers can enjoy the view of the picturesque old town and Lake Zurich, no matter where they’re sitting.

FACTS
Stage: Swiss National Museum, Zurich – Zürichhorn
Journey time: 30 mins

EXCURSION TIPS
 * Grossmünster & Fraumünster churches
 * Old town
 * Lindenhof
 * Bürkliplatz
 * Sechseläutenplatz
 * Uetliberg

FOOD & DRINK 
A place to eat and drink is offered in the form of the ship’s own restaurant.

TIMETABLE
All connections here [https://www.zsg.ch/en/]

TICKET
Tickets can be purchased online [https://ticketshop.zvv.ch/home?1], at the sales outlets on Bürkliplatz, or on board the ship itself.

RESERVATIONS
No need to reserve a seat – you can sit where you like.

data.name: Cheese Fondue Cruise
data.abstract: Just the thing during the cold time of the year: the Swiss national dish served in a traditional «caquelon» (fondue dish) during a leisurely evening cruise on board the heated Lake Zurich ship.
data.description: The ships depart at 19:30 from Zurich and return back in Zurich at 21:45, door closes at: 22:05. During the one-and-a-half-hour cruise you’re taken on a beautiful trip on Lake Zurich and served a delicious cheese fondue.

data.name: Ladies only wellness
data.abstract: High above Zurich’s rooftops, women can enjoy deep relaxation with a wellness programme for like-minded sisters.
data.description: The spa area is small but charming and exclusively reserved for women. A steam bath, Finnish sauna and biosauna await. Relax in comfort among the large, pleasantly warm cherry stone pillows. The separate quiet room offers plenty of space to relax and unwind. The ladies can cool off on the roof terrace on the 6th floor and enjoy a fantastic view of the city, the mountains and Lake Zurich.

data.name: Sheep Piece by Henry Moore
data.abstract: The lakeside promenade at Zürichhorn is home to one of the typical works by the English sculptor Henry Moore. Since the time of the Moore exhibition in Zurich in 1976 this abstract bronze sculpture "Sheep Piece" has been admired as a public work of art.
data.description: Due to his rural origins, Henry Moore was an ardent observer of nature. For his "Sheep Piece", he chose a format that was both monumental and romantic. The name was derived from its former location in a field where sheep grazed. With their oversized bodies, Moore was seeking to attract our attention to these rather mundane animals which we scarcely notice any more.

data.name: Grossmünster
data.abstract: The Grossmünster is an Evangelical Protestant church in the Old Town of Zurich and the city's landmark. The view from the church towers is spectacular: far across Lake Zurich to the Alps.
data.description:
In the first half of the 16th century, the Grossmünster served as the starting point of the Reformation under Huldrych Zwingli and Heinrich Bullinger. The characteristic tops of its neo-Gothic towers were added by Johann Caspar Voegeli and John Hagge Mille from 1781 to 1787. Between 1913 and 1915 the interior renovations were completed by Gustav Gull and Hermann Fietz.

Particularly worth seeing are the glass windows by Sigmar Polke, the Romanesque crypt, the Romanesque capitals in the church and cloister, the stained glass windows by Augusto Giacometti (1932), the bronze doors by Otto Münch (1935 and 1950), and the Reformation museum in the cloister. Guided tours are available.

The so-called Karlsturm is one of the two Grossmünster towers of this famous Zurich landmark. 187 stairs lead from the nave up to the tower vantage point – from where visitors have bird’s-eye views over the Zurich rooftops [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/zurichs-old-town/]and lake [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/lake-zurich/]as well as majestic Alpine summits on the horizon.

data.name: Viaduct Arches
data.abstract: Life has returned to the area under the arches of the railway viaduct built in 1894 in Zurich-West. A 550-yd-long urban meeting place invites you to stroll, shop, enjoy, eat and drink.
data.description: A shopping paradise has been created under 36 viaduct arches. The colorful mix of delicatessens, studio galleries, sport and fashion boutiques is open to the public. At the heart of it all is the Market Hall where 20 farmers and food vendors from the area offer their wares.

data.name: Dada art movement city tour
data.abstract: On this fascinating city tour, Dada fans will learn how the eclectic artists, writers and performers found their way to Zurich and how they turned the city upside down.
data.description:
Content of the tour:
 * Discover the most important Dada venues
 * Hear the most thrilling and captivating stories
 * Explore the city from a Dadaist perspective


For those who want to learn about Dada in Zurich, a guided tour is a must. 
 * Dada today: Cabaret Voltaire, the birthplace of the movement, Haus Konstruktiv, the Kunsthaus in combination with local cuisine
 * Popular meeting places for Dadaists in Zurich: Cabaret Voltaire, Odeon, Terrasse (formerly Café de la Terrasse), Zunfthaus zur Waag, Zunfthaus zur Meise, Kaufleuten


Click here for more information and dates: www.zuerich.com [https://www.zuerich.com/en/visit/tours-excursions/dada-city-tour#internal]

data.name: Gastro tour - UrbanCoffee
data.abstract: 400 years of coffee culture in three hours: discover the history of Zurich´s coffeehouses on a fascinating tour of indulgence.
data.description: Although coffee has been around for over 1,000 years, this popular beverage only found its way to Zurich about four centuries ago. So how has coffee culture in Zurich developed since then? Where does the best coffee come from and what determines the taste? These and many other questions are answered in the course of the "UrbanCoffee" tour. But don´t worry: the three-hour event is not a history lesson, but a fascinating and indulgent tour of the city´s most beautiful coffeehouses.
