data.name: Communication in the animal kingdom
data.abstract: The "Communication in the animal kingdom" guided tour at Zoo Zurich is dedicated to various forms of communication among animals.
data.description:
Animal communication is one of the most fascinating things zoology has to offer. In the animal kingdom very simple but very effective forms of communication can be found. Communication is vital in finding a partner, creating a bond between the mother and her young, danger warning or camouflage. Discover different forms of communication in the animal kingdom on a guided tour through Zoo Zurich.

Group guided tours
Zoo Zurich offers exciting group guided tours on various topics from the animal world. Also new tours through the Australia enclosure, including koalas, kangaroos, emus and the impressive giant monitor lizards.

data.name: Fondue at Chalet Züriberg
data.abstract: High above the rooftops of Zurich, you will find coziness as you otherwise only know from the mountains. A genuine wooden chalet, a crackling fireplace and a magnificent view. Combined with the unique cheese and meat fondue specialties, this is a real treat.
data.description:
A delightful chalet evening with us begins on the terrace with the view over the city and the lake. A mug of mulled wine and hot chestnuts are the perfect start to an event before moving on to the chalet which awaits the guests with it's cozy warmth created through the fireplace. Here, fondue plays the leading role, be it cheese or meat. Whether it is the original Swiss fondue, with racy chilli or truffles and champagne, there is something for every taste.

We are convinced, taht genuine pleasure can only come from good ingredients. That's why we choose our suppliers very carefully. The best cheese fondue starts of course with an excellent cheese. We have found one nearby in Embrach, on the Guldenberg farm of the Lienhard family. The quality of their produce is the top priority for the Lienhard family. Their cows are also fed on potatoes and are milked without any automatic milking machines. The milk is bottled on the farm immediately and is processed into the full-bodied cheese at the dairy in Embrach. We also care about the fondue chinoise where we use only Swiss meat supplied by the Ziegler butchers in Zurich.

data.name: Flussbad Oberer and Unterer Letten
data.abstract: Swim in the river? Yes, in Zurich you can! The Unterer Letten and Oberer Letten river bathing facilities provide swimming channels in the Limmat River.
data.description: The Oberer Letten has a 400-metre swimming channel in the Limmat and a two-metre high diving platform. Two beach volleyball courts on the opposite side, a boules pitch and a food kiosk complete the offer. The Unterer Letten is located near Zurich West and has a 100-metre swimming channel in the Limmat, a non-swimmer’s pool, a children's wading pool and a diving platform.

data.name: Photo Spot Stäfa
data.abstract: Ötikon harbour, one of the most impressive and oldest settlements on Lake Zurich, was founded back when people and goods mainly travelled by water. From 1636 to 1868, the granary opposite Gasthof Sonne undertook cargo handling. To the east, the gun club closed off the harbour, offering target practice on the lake shore. The bustling tempo prompted a number of inns to open. The Sonne, Rössli and Löwen all enjoyed a golden age from 1636 thanks to the market. The stone landing stage opened in 1867.

data.name: Fondue Tram
data.abstract: When the fondue season gets going why not jump on the bandwagon: true aficionados of the Swiss specialty climb aboard the veteran tram and travel past Zurich’s prettiest sites.
data.description: While the lights of Zurich pass by outside, time stands still inside the veteran vehicle built in 1930. During the roughly two-hour ride, passengers are treated to ‘Glühwein’, a Grisons starter platter, cheese fondue, dessert and coffee.

data.name: Kuhn Rikon factory tour
data.abstract: Founded in 1926 in Rikon, Kuhn Rikon is a manufacturing enterprise for cookware in Zurich’s Tösstal valley. It is known in particular for pressure cookers under the brand name Duromatic, as well as the double-walled Durotherm cookware.
data.description: For clubs, companies and all other people interested in knowing how this particular cookware is made, the company is pleased to organize viewing tours of the production process. Following a tour you also have the opportunity to shop in the factory outlet at favorable conditions.

data.name: Excursion: Zwingli's Beginnings and End, Wildhaus and Zug
data.abstract: Visitors interested in Zwingli's beginnings can visit the Zwinglihaus in Wildhaus, 80 miles east of Zürich. A small museum occupies the farmhouse where the Reformer was born in 1484, and includes displays of period furniture and Bibles.
data.description: Zwingli celebrated his first mass as a priest in the local church before it became Protestant. Zwingli's life ended at the Battle of Kappel in 1531 when the Reformer died of a sword wound. A monument marks the occasion of his death near the town of Zug, about 20 miles south of Zürich.

data.name: Bachtel
data.abstract: Today's Bachtel lookout tower was built in 1986 and is 75 meters high. A viewing platform at 30 meters above ground offers beautiful views of Lake Zurich, the Linth Plain, the foothills of the Alps and the Alpstein mountain range.
data.description: The first wooden tower built on the Bachtel in 1873 was destroyed by a storm in 1890. In 1893 it was replaced by a steel lattice tower which was removed in 1985 because it was not suitable as an aerial mast. It was reconstructed on the Pfannenstiel where it still stands today. An information panel with the names and outlines of the mountains visible from the Bachtel tower was installed on the viewing platform. In good weather the views range from Bachtel mountain to the north all the way to the Black Forest.

data.name: Otter installation
data.abstract: The natural pond is part of the Zurich Wilderness Park.
data.description: Young and old are always delighted when one of the animals appears. The otters are best observed at dusk and during the day you can see the traces of their nocturnal activity. Information boards tell the story of the otters.

data.name: The Grossmünster (Great Church)
data.abstract: Any religious tour to Zürich must begin at the Romanesque Grossmünster, symbol of the city and Zürich's religious heart and soul. This is the site where legend says Sts. Felix and Regula are buried, the cathedral that Charlemagne is said to have founded himself. More importantly, it was here in the Grossmünster that Huldrych Zwingli preached a new brand of Christianity in the early 16th century, one that would change the face of Switzerland and Protestantism.
data.description: The interior of the Grossmünster bears evidence of Zwingli's influence. The cathedral stands stripped of any pre-Reformation statuary or ornamentation (save a few stone carvings of Charlemagne); they were removed to guard against the distractions of religious artwork, and to impress upon visitors the sufficiency of God alone in one's salvation. Beneath the apse, the cathedral's 12th-century crypt houses 15th-century murals of Felix and Regula, as well as a well-worn, 15th-century statue of Charlemagne. Visit before noon and the cathedral's east-facing apse glows red and blue, lit up by Augusto Giacometti's 20th-century stained glass windows.

data.name: Fallenbach Canyon: Amden’s Rain Forest-like canyon
data.abstract: The adventure-packed Fallenbach Canyon by Amden am Wallensee offers a truly diverse canyoning experience close to Zurich. Ideal for beginners and interesting for the experienced.
data.description:
Whoever reckons you have to go down to Ticino to enjoy a great canyoning experience is wrong! The Fallenbach Canyon is characterized through great diversity in a most attractive natural setting that leads in part through stretches of water similar to those of the Rain Forest. The smoothly eroded rocks are for the most part adorned with lush-green ferns and shimmering moss, between which crystal-clear pools of green lead to the depths of the wildly bubbling waters. 

A canyon well suited to beginners (as well as children) with easy initial stretch in a wooded environment, in preparation for the second slightly more difficult stretch of water. All jumps are optional, and you can reach lower levels courtesy of a rope and canyon guide! And those unexpectedly changing their minds midway can easily exit the canyon - although to be honest, who’s likely to want to miss out on adventurous water slides, exciting jumps and the fun of being lowered with a rope. Abseil descents into the depths directly by a waterfall – or clambering down a safe cascade of water in a similar manner are unforgettable experiences in the Amden Canyon - and open to all! INFORMATION

Canyon: Fallenbachschlucht
Where: Amden/Weesen
Activities: Canyoning 
Levels of difficulty: + to ++

data.name: Winterthur city discovery
data.abstract: Just 20 minutes away from Zurich is the cultural city of Winterthur, with countless museums and an active music and comedy scene.
data.description:
Information
Winterthur is home to 16 museums, which are often located in fabulous landscaped parks. International renown is enjoyed by the collections of Oskar Reinhart (“Am Römerholz”, “Am Stadtgarten”), the Villa Flora, and the art museum. In addition, thanks to the photo museum and the Swiss Foundation of Photography, it is reputed to be Europe’s centre of excellence for photography. 

The heart of Winterthur beats in the pedestrian area of the picturesque old town: shops, restaurants, markets and festivals enliven the historical walls. The Technorama is ideal for a very special experience. The science centre, equipped with 500 experiment stations, guarantees entertainment for young and old.

data.name: Photo Spot Lake Lucerne Car Ferry
data.abstract: The only 'mobile photo spot' on the Grand Tour of Switzerland. In 1928, Alois Waser-Bucher, an entrepreneur from Nidwald, took interest in the Beckenried–Gersau car ferry project and, subsequently, had a ferry constructed in Uerikon on Lake Zurich in 1929. On Whit Sunday 1930, the ferry service was opened with the motor vessel ‘Tellsprung’ (‘Tell’s Leap’) carrying 20 cars. In 1959, a local hotelier bought the ferry and had it extensively rebuilt by Bodan Wharf on Lake Constance. The new ferry, which can carry up to 45 cars, started its service on Whit Saturday 1964, and has been owned by the F&R Group Beckenried since 2016.

data.name: From Waste to Energy
data.abstract: Experience first hand how ERZ, Zurich Disposal and Recycling Services, turns burnable trash into CO2 neutral thermal heat and environmentally friendly electricity.
data.description:
During the exciting tour of our Incineration Plant, or better said, our „Waste-to-Energy-Plant“, we will follow the waste see it being burned and see how it’s converted into usable energy. Ask how to receive a free tour of our plant. 

Highlights: 
 * Experience a furnace full of information, emotions and entertainment
 * Hear a symphony of sounds Open your eyes to an enormous installation
 * Open your eyes to an enormous installation
 * Discover how the power of our fire converts waste into clean Energy


Included: Tour, Information

data.name: From Sewage to Clean Water
data.abstract: See how the experts from ERZ (Zurich Disposal and Recycling Services) cleanse between 150,000 and 500,000 cubic meters of sewage water and where it’s released back into the Limmat River as clean water.
data.description:
In this four part cleansing process, you will witness the solid and solute polluted matter being taken out of the sewage water and learn how the residue of that matter is transformed into something ecological and useful so that our water cycle remains clean. 

Highlights: 
 * Experience a fountain of information, emotions and entertainment
 * Smell a plethora of scents
 * See a display of all the strange things that have been fished out the sewage water
 * Ease your body and mind by playing with the process of our sewage treatment


Included: Tour, Information 
Not Included: Travel to and from departure location, Food & Beverages

data.name: Schongiland amusement park
data.abstract: This family-friendly amusement park in central Switzerland offers fun and thrills for young and old alike. Just 35 kilometres from Aarau, Lucerne, Zug and Zurich, Schongiland is a popular day out for families and is constantly adding to its list of attractions.
data.description:
With rides including the Dragon Flight Swing, Schongi Loop, Butterfly and many more besides, Schongiland is a fun-packed day out that your children will love. The highlight is the 380-metre long summer sled run – the only covered (and therefore all-weather) sled run of its type in Switzerland. Open from March through to October, Schongiland offers a wide range of attractions. Test your balance on a unicycle, slide down the tunnels on the Slide of Hell and bounce on the bouncy castles. Then move on to explore how water carves out its own paths in the water playground. 

If you’re feeling peckish, head to the 70-seat self-service restaurant or the 200-seat garden café to pick up something to eat. For those who prefer to bring their own food with them, the park has picnic tables and a popular BBQ area.

More information: schongiland.ch [https://schongiland.ch/en/]

data.name: Sihltal - Sihlsprung - Sihlwald
data.abstract: From the Sihlsprung up to the entrance to metropolitan Zürich, the valley is a mixture of urban and rustic landscapes. The origin of the Sihl River is to be found on the 2283-meter Drusberg. The Sihl flows through the Sihl Lake near Einsiedeln and meanders through the Sihl Valley (Sihltal) towards Zürich.
data.description: A 4-hour hiking tour starts in Schönenberg ZH and proceeds alongside the Sihl River via Sihlbrugg to Sihlwald. Shortly after Sihlmatt, the hiking trail takes you to an old tunnel of the Zürich Water Supply. After the tunnel the gorge becomes narrow and turns into the Sihlsprung, or Sihl Rapids. The Sihl wends its way for several meters through high rock faces. Subsequently, rapids and sand banks define the landscape. Near Sihlbrugg you have to leave this impressive natural landscape for a short while and cross a busy road. Now your hiking tour skirts the riverside of the Sihl before reaching Sihlwald. At Sihlwald railway station you will also find the visitor centre of the Zurich Wilderness Park with a museum, an otter enclosure that is freely accessible at all times and an aquarium.

data.name: Food for thought
data.abstract: A matter of taste. There is no such thing as a single Swiss cuisine. As you travel through Switzerland you’ll find Berner Rösti, buttery home-fried potatoes in Bern; Malakoff cheese fritters in Canton Vaud; and cornmeal specialities and freshly caught perch from Lake Constance in Canton St. Gallen. The Valais is famous for its raclette, melted mountain cheese served with steamed new potatoes and pickles; Graubünden for its Capuns, tender dumplings wrapped in Swiss chard leaves; Zürich for its Geschnetzeltes, creamy shredded veal; and Ticino for its luganighe sausages and fabulous risotto. Switzerland has an incredible number of traditional regional dishes – a world record in proportion to its size.
data.description:
FLAVOURS OF THE MARKET
Every city and large village holds a market once or twice a week, with the freshest foods from farmers, butchers, bakers and cheese makers. The markets in Bellinzona [http://www.bellinzonaturismo.ch/framework/Desktopdefault.aspx?menu_index=31&menu_id=381] , Chur [http://www.churtourismus.ch], Basel [http://www.basel.com/en.cfm/baselinfo/baselbilder/offer-BaselInfoBT-Speziell-236445.html] and Solothurn [http://www.mysolothurn.com/markte?opt=viewObj&wid=157&objId=318] are particularly enticing. 

TRADITIONAL FOOD AT THE SWISS OPEN-AIR MUSEUM
This museum in Ballenberg [http://www.ballenberg.ch] near Brienz works to keep history alive – and that includes the history of food. From spring to autumn, you can watch the butcher, the baker, the cheese maker and the chocolate maker at work. It’s enough to make your mouth water… 

A DELICIOUS HIKE
The high path between Chasseral and Frinvilliers near Biel offers not only spectacular views, but also the chance to visit a dozen or so métairies along the way: alpine huts where regional specialities such as cheese, Rösti and ham are served. 

DIRECT FROM THE LAND
Nearly all the fruits, vegetables, jams, wines, cheeses, and sausages from the canton of Vaud can be found in a single shop, La Ferme vaudoise [http://www.lafermeyverdon.ch] in Yverdon-les-Bains. 


LADLE IN HAND
You can learn some of the secrets of Swiss cooking by enrolling in a cookery course. These take place all over the country, from Geneva to the Engadine, and from Schaffhausen to Ticino. More experienced cooks may choose to study with one of Switzerland’s superchefs: Chef of the Year 2007 Markus Neff at the Hotel Fletschhorn [http://www.fletschhorn.ch] in Saas-Fee, Vreni Giger at the Restaurant Jägerhof [http://www.jaegerhof.ch] in St. Gallen, Kurt Röösli at the Hotel Waldhaus [http://www.waldhaus-sils.ch] in Sils- Maria, Urs Gschwend at the Hotel Giardino [http://www.giardino.ch/?lang=eng] in Ascona, or Irene Dörig at Irene’s Cuisine [http://www.irenes-cuisine.ch] in Friedlisberg near Zürich.

data.name: St. Peterskirche (St. Peter's Church)
data.abstract: St. Peterskirche was a landmark in Swiss Reformation history, the home of Zürich's first appointed Protestant pastor, Leo Jud. (Zwingli was appointed as a Catholic priest and later converted.)
data.description: Zwingli's close friend and colleague, Jud arrived at St. Peter's in 1523; Rudolf Gwalther, Zwingli's son-in-law, served as pastor here beginning in 1541. St. Peterskirche enjoys the distinction of bearing Europe's largest clock face.

data.name: Sihlpark Wellness
data.abstract: In Schindellegi high above Lake Zurich, “Sihlpark Wellness” has established an oasis of well-being where day-to-day life is deliberately brought to a halt.
data.description:
“Sihlpark Wellness” offers a special kind of relaxation and pampering programme in an area covering over 1,500 square metres: it includes a hammam, two expansive saunas, an outdoor salt water pool, extensive beauty treatment options as well as a fitness centre and bistro with healthy and natural products.

Book the day spa, for example, or find out more about the attractive private spa suite offers. Of course, there are also other interesting packages for a relaxing and enjoyable time for two.

Getting there: By train to “Schindellegi” and then on foot (2km) or by taxi or car (parking available).

data.name: Spatz Männi Adventure Trail
data.abstract: The naughty sparrow Männi is clever, daring and sometimes rather cheeky. On the Adventure Trail on the Atzmännig Mountain in Zürich’s Oberland children can experience the story of Männi, written by Andrew Bond, and accompany the bird on its adventures.
data.description:
The Adventure Trail is meant primarily for young children (between 2 and 10 years) – here the kids can be naughty mudlarks, climb in the nests of Männi and Frieda, throw pinecones at the hunter, make lots of noise, and show their bravery in the horrible and scary doddering gorge. If they still have energy after the walk, they can continue to frolic in the Atzmännig Adventure Park. INFORMATION

The Spatz Männi Adventure Trail in the Atzmännig Sport and Leisure Center in Goldingen is open from mid-April to the beginning of November. The book “Frechspatz Männi“ by Andrew Bond is available in bookstores or Online-Shop under www.frechspatz.ch [http://www.frechspatz.ch]

data.name: Photo Spot Rapperswil-Jona
data.abstract: Rapperswil-Jona is called ‘Town of Roses on Lake Zurich’ for a reason. More than 20,000 plants can be found blooming in four rose gardens as well as in public spaces. The picturesque old town with its medieval castle, as well as the marvellous lake promenade, lend the town an almost southern flair. Several historic buildings, numerous festivals and cultural events as well as the Knies Kinderzoo of the National Circus Knie shape the city’s atmosphere at Lake Zurich.

data.name: Stand-up paddle city tour
data.abstract: Explore the city of Zurich from a different perspective ‒ in the course of an active leisure pursuit of a very special kind!
data.description:
On this guided tour, you will discover some of Zurich’s history-steeped places of interest from the water – standing on a paddling board. Participants are introduced to the art of stand-up paddling and at the same time learn all kinds of interesting historical facts about the city of Zurich along its waterways. 

Available in following languages: German, English, French, Spanish.GOOD TO KNOW

 * Material hire (stand-up paddle and board) included
 * Introduction to stand-up paddling

data.name: Lötschberg tunnel
data.abstract: With the opening of the Lötschberg basis-tunnel the journey from Zurich or Basel to the canton of Valais was reduced to 2 hours.
data.description: In an informative guided tour through the Lötschberg basis-tunnel, which connects Frutigen in the canton of Bern and Raron in the canton of Valais, the participants are given a lot of information on the building process as well as the operation of the most modern railway tunnel in the world. The tour is in german (other languages on request).

data.name: Industrialization Trail
data.abstract: Not far from Zurich, the Industrialization Trail Zurich Oberland lets you travel back in time.
data.description: All along the way, grand historical buildings dating from the era of industrialization beckon. You may also want to visit the new Museum of textile machinery at Neuthal. Starting in Uster, you are free to decide the distance you want to cover (total length of 30 kilometers).

data.name: Saturday City Tours
data.abstract: Discover a different aspect of Zurich each month.
data.description:
Where are most romantic spots in the city? How did Zurich-West develop into a trendy quarter? Where does money play a particularly important role? On our series of guided city walks, held on the first Saturday of the month, urban explorers can discover the answers to these and other fascinating questions and on each occasion get to know Zurich from a different perspective. GOOD TO KNOW

 * Price: CHF 25 
 * Language: German
 * Departure Time: 4.00pm
 * Duration: 2 hours

data.name: Photo Spot Rhine Falls
data.abstract: 150 metres wide, thundering 23 metres down into the depths before your eyes is Europe’s largest waterfall, a spectacular example of the power of nature. Experience the roaring spectacle of nature at first hand from the ‘Känzeli’ platform. The rock in the middle of the river can be reached by boat and a short ascent on foot. Laufen Castle, enthroned above the water for more than a thousand years, ranks amongst Canton Zurich’s cultural heritage sites. The foaming waters of the Rhine Falls are mesmerising at any time of day, including the evenings when they are illuminated.

data.name: Photo Spot Meilen
data.abstract: Meilen’s lakeside promenade invites you to take a stroll and have some fun. Back in the 17th century both people and goods would be transported across the lake, a practice that continued up until the railways along the right side of Lake Zurich were put into operation in 1894. Enjoy the view of the lake, reaching from the Albis chain of hills all the way to the Glarus Alps. Discover the Lake Zurich Region on board the Horgen–Meilen Lake Zurich ferry or one of the Lake Zurich Navigation Company (ZSG)’s boats or ships. All aboard!
data.description:
Address:

Parking:

Distance on foot:
Two minutes from Sterne car park or the parking for Gasthof Löwen.

Indulge in the buffet, featuring specialities from across the world, and help yourself to drinks from the bar. 

Spend the evening singing along to classics like Oops!… I Did It Again and It’s Raining Men. With over 100 songs to choose from, you can really let loose and sing your heart out! The Tonbandlounge on the first floor of the 25hours Hotel Zurich Langstrasse is the ideal venue for an exclusive karaoke party.

data.name: Love Stories – passion, love and happy endings
data.abstract: This tour is for anyone who is in love, engaged or married, as well as for anyone who intends to be.
data.description: You will find out where the married Richard Wagner met the love of his life, what the function of the marriage room was at city hall, and who discouraged Casanova from entering a monastery in Zurich. This Love Stories tour provides some romantic, funny and exciting moments. A happy ending is guaranteed.

data.name: Löwenbräu Areal
data.abstract: Museums, galleries, art publishers - the Löwenbräu Areal is a much loved venue for art enthusiasts. The changing exhibitions of contemporary art have transformed this former brewery into a landmark cultural centre.
data.description:
An exciting mix of new and old has been created in Zurich West on the Löwenbräu-Areal premises. Two new high-rises stretch above the old brewery and further emphasize the architectural shape provided by the silos. A black, elegant building 230 feet high and with an overhang giving it the appearance of a cobra looms up behind the old brewery. The industrial past is still very visible, and the characteristic historic building from 1897, the chimney and the steel silo all nicely preserved. 

A unique mix of international artists, trades people and people who call this place home make best use of the premises.

data.name: Following General Suvorov
data.description: In 1799 General Alexander Suvorov travelled across Switzerland with an army of 21,000 men. Where did they fight and where did they spend the nights? On an excursion from Zurich to Muothatal the guests visit various monuments and a monastery.

price.description: CHF 295.00 per person CHF 0.00 incl. transport CHF 0.00 excl. food

data.name: Jules Verne Bar
data.abstract: Breathtaking view from the tower at this former observatory.
data.description: The Panorama Bar, high above the rooftops of Zurich, is a popular meeting place during the day as well as at night when the lights of the city are on. The view over the city and the Alps across Lake Zurich is simply breathtaking. The perfect place for romantics.

data.name: Niederdorf
data.abstract: The celebrated Old Town district of the Niederdorf is affectionately known by locals as the Dörfli – the “little village”.
data.description: With its winding, car-free alleys, its emblematic Grossmünster [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/grossmuenster/]church and its many small boutiques, antiquarian bookshops and craft studios, it is a delight to explore both by day and in the evening. The Niederdorf also perfectly embodies the city’s unique charm. The Schober-Péclard boutique and confectionery, for example, is a listed building that stylishly combines the elements that make a trip to Zurich [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/zurich/]so special: history, architecture and shopping.

data.name: Solzhenitsyn’s hideaway
data.description: Zurich’s mayor Sigmund Widmer used to have a vacation home in Bauma-Sternenberg where Alexander Solzhenitsyn was once in hiding. The Russian author was deported from the Soviet Union in 1974 and briefly lived in the Zurich Oberland. A tour of the house sheds light on his life’s story.

price.description: CHF 295.00 per person CHF 0.00 incl. transport CHF 0.00 excl. food

data.name: Two-day Bollywood tour
data.description: Since 1964 over 200 Indian movies have been shot in Switzerland. The blockbusters from Bollywood brought more and more guests from India to Switzerland. The guests visit some of the original locations of Bollywood films in Zurich, Lucerne and the Bernese Oberland with the guides of Erwin Tours.

data.name: Gastro tour - the classic
data.abstract: Take a tour with two experts who know the local gastro scene intimately, and enjoy each course on the menu in a different restaurant.
data.description: This exciting tour combines a guided walk around the city, a five-course meal and an entertaining evening programme.Over the course of 5 hours, you will visit at least 4 restaurants, covering a distance of 3 kilometres. At each stop-off point on your journey, you will be able to enjoy one course of the menu and hear entertaining anecdotes about Zurich’s gastronomy.One of the two professional local guides will accompany you throughout the evening and reveal the city from a different perspective. An exciting and unforgettable experience that will leave you with delicious memories.

data.name: Winter fun on ice
data.abstract: The atmosphere at the Dolder Ice Complex is unique: surrounded by wooded countryside, this 6,000 square meter ice rink - the biggest artificial ice rink in Switzerland - is a quiet and relaxing place.
data.description:
The complex, which has been renovated and enlarged in recent years, blends harmoniously into the background. With other leisure facilities such as a swimming pool (with wave-making equipment) and minigolf course close by the Dolder ice rink it is a popular meeting place for sports fans of all ages and an attractive day trip destination for anyone in the Zurich region.

How to get there:
Streetcars No. 3, 8 or 15 up to the "Römerhof" stop; by Dolder train to the terminus, then a short walk.
By bus: No. 751 to the stop "Dreiwiesen", then a 2-minute walk. 

Opening hours:
October - March:
Mon-Sat: 9 AM-10:20 PM / Sun: 9 AM-5:40 PM

data.name: Stand up paddling city tour
data.description: A different way to explore the city of Zurich – from the water. A city tour on the river to visit historic sites while balancing on the surfboard. Previous experience in stand up paddling is not necessary. The paddle guides are well versed in both water sports and culture.

data.name: Bahnhofstrasse
data.abstract: Stretching for 1.4 kilometres from the main railway station to the lake, the Bahnhofstrasse is one of the most famous shopping streets in the world.
data.description:
Strung along it like pearls on a necklace are department stores, boutiques and jewellery shops; the further you stroll towards the lake, the more exclusive the shops become. 

The Paradeplatz is the heart of the Bahnhofstrasse and serves as an important tram junction close to Lake Zurich [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/lake-zurich/]. Since the major Swiss banks set up their headquarters here, the Paradeplatz has made a name for itself as Switzerland’s biggest money-handling centre. Along the way, alleys such as Rennweg and Augustinergasse lead off into the picturesque Old Town [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/zurichs-old-town/].

image.name: Bahhofstrasse, Zurich, May 17, 2014. Photo by Elisabeth Real

data.name: Moods
data.abstract: The premier location for jazz, funk, soul and blues.
data.description: Moods runs its popular programme near the Schiffbau in the trendy Zurich West district. Well-known names as well as outstanding newcomers delight their audiences almost every day with jazz, funk, soul and blues.

data.name: Team cooking
data.abstract: You will learn, laugh and enjoy – a memorable end to a meeting and the perfect team building event. The guests prepare the menu themselves, supervised and instructed by the 25hours kitchen and service team.
data.description:
As its name suggests, the 25hours Hotel Zurich West is in the west of the city. It has a lively mixture of vibrant colours, authentic local flair and a homely atmosphere. The hotel is very much in touch with its surroundings and combines work by the Zurich-based designer Alfredo Häberli with creative art. Embodying the hotel company’s tongue-in-cheek humour, the 25hours Hotel Zurich West never takes itself too seriously and shows what the city has to offer other than banking, chocolate and watches.

The Küchenclub („kitchen club“) with its bulthaup show kitchen and its newest generation of Miele kitchen appliances is the ideal location for your team cooking.

Included in the package: 
 * Three- or four course menu, prepared by the guests (choice of menu in advance, one menu for the entire group)
 * Beverages for max. 4 hours: Prosecco, white and red wine chosen by the restaurant manager, mineral water, coffee, espresso and tea (every additional hour + CHF 15)
 * Professional supervision by the 25hours kitchen and service team
 * Aprons for use during the event
 * Use of beamer & screen and BOSE sound system. W-LAN, free of charge for all guests
 * Take-away: small present and recipe booklet of the cooked menu for every participant
 * After the event: CD with photos of the team cooking


Since too many cooks spoil the broth, the team cooking is available for max. 15 participants. If you are a larger group, there are several possibilities: for example you can split up the group and one part does a wine tasting while the others play table tennis.

data.name: Kitchenbattle
data.abstract: The name is the product. If you book this team event you are cooking for victory.
data.description:
Not only fame and honour awaits the winning team, but also awesome prizes. Based on the model of the many tv shows the group will be splitted into two teams, which compete against each other. You can chose whether you want us to decide which team wins the spoils or if you want to do it yourselves.

As its name suggests, the 25hours Hotel Zurich West is in the west of the city. It has a lively mixture of vibrant colours, authentic local flair and a homely atmosphere. The hotel is very much in touch with its surroundings and combines work by the Zurich-based designer Alfredo Häberli with creative art. Embodying the hotel company’s tongue-in-cheek humour, the 25hours Hotel Zurich West never takes itself too seriously and shows what the city has to offer other than banking, chocolate and watches.

data.name: Rimini-Bar
data.abstract: The open-air bar on the water.
data.description: Zurich is renowned for its bathing pool bars or Badi-Bars. At dusk, the lakeside and riverside pools are transformed into sophisticated bars and lounges directly by the water. It’s the same with the Rimini-Bar. Here, guests chill out on oriental cushions and enjoy specialities grilled on the spit and cool drinks. Open during the summer months (closed in bad weather), with "Rimini in the tent" each October.

data.name: Segway
data.description: Experience an exciting voyage of discovery through Zurich city centre on a Segway PT i2 using your Segway Pass. Guided city tours include short stops at famous sights, such as Lake Zurich, Bahnhofstrasse, Münsterhof and Limmatquai. Beautiful districts and squares are explored, and comprehensive commentary is provided. The two-hour tour includes a driving lesson lasting about 20 minutes.

data.name: Pavilion sculpture by Max Bill
data.abstract: The Swiss artist Max Bill created this walk-in "Pavilion Sculpture" in 1983, which may be viewed on its prime position on the Bahnhofstrasse. The stone sculpture, with its pillars, arches and plinths, is certainly one of the best-known works by the late Max Bill.
data.description: Max Bill (1908-1994) made a name for himself as an artist, architect, painter, graphic designer and sculptor. In the 1930’s, his success made him an exponent of the Swiss art scene. He devoted himself to concrete art, which has the aim of translating abstract ideas into concrete objects. Together with other Swiss artists, he was a representative of the Zurich School of Concrete Art, which was inspired by Wassily Kandinsky and Paul Klee.

image.copyrightHolder: ©2010 Zuerich Tourism / Photo by Serge Baumeler

data.name: Seebad Enge & sauna by the lake
data.abstract: Two pontoons floating on the water like a raft provide a mixed and women’s-only pool, both with lake access and magnificent views of the Alps.
data.description: To experience Zurich at its best, cool off at the Seebad Enge near the Bürkliplatz and bathe in the lake. Admire the wide views of the Alps on the horizon, enjoy the outdoor bar with grill and salads while traditional massage, yoga classes and the sauna by the lake complete the picture. The latter is especially worth visiting in winter because after your time in the sauna you can jump straight into the lake (4-6 degrees).

data.name: Treno Gottardo
data.abstract: ​The Treno Gottardo runs hourly over the 120-year-old Gotthard panorama line to the sun-kissed corner of Switzerland. The panoramic ride promises impressive views of rugged mountain faces and deep blue lakes as well as plenty of Mediterranean flair with palm trees and stately residences.
data.description:
Bustling cities, historic buildings and a great variety of nature and leisure activities – all of this can be experienced on the Treno Gottardo. The diversity of Switzerland with one single train! The new train, equipped with bistro zone and family area, runs hourly from Zurich, Basel and Lucerne to Locarno. Travel most comfortably along lakes and mountains over the historic Gotthard panorama route right to Locarno in the sun-kissed corner of Switzerland. Benvenuti!


FACTS TRENO GOTTARDO
Route: Zürich/Basel/Luzern – Bellinzona – Locarno

Duration: Zürich – Locarno: 3 h 20 min
Basel – Locarno: 4 h 22 min
Luzern – Locarno: 3 h 7 min 

EXCURSION TIPS
 * Lucerne [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/lucerne/]with its numerous sights such as the chapel bridge or the lion's monument
 * Lake Lucerne [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/boat-cruises-on-lake-lucerne/] with its impressive fleet of steamboats
 * Altdorf [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/altdorf/], main town of the canton of Uri, with the world famous Tell monument
 * The 1882 inaugurated Gotthard panorama route with the church of Wassen that can be seen from three different angles during the ride
 * The Leventina [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/leventina/]with its spectacular surroundings – with the steep funicular railway to Lake Ritom and the Strada Alta, or by cableway to Lake Tremorgio
 * The castles of Bellinzona [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/the-fortress-of-bellinzona/], part of UNESCO World Heritage since the year 2000
 * Locarno [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/locarno/]with its bustling Piazza Grande, Lake Maggiore and the famous pilgrimage church Madonna del Sasso

FOOD & BEVERAGES
Two bistro zones with snack and beverage vending machines as well as a coffee maker.

TIMETABLE
The timetable can be found here [http://sbb.ch].

TICKET
 This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]

RESERVATION
 * Seat reservation available for individual travellers
 * Seat reservation required for groups of 10 or more persons (no surcharge)

 Go to reservations [https://sbb.ch]

data.name: Shilwald (Wildlife Park) Route
data.description:
The Sihlwald (Wildlife Park) Route takes you from Thalwil over the Albis Pass to Hausen am Albis. And from Albis you continually enjoy new breathtaking views over Lake Zurich. The Zürichsee-Rundweg (round path alongside the lake) provides views of mansions, tidy towns and natural shoreline as you pass –and of course the Sihlwald nature park is a great close-by attraction with its pristine and almost untouched nature in contrast to the urban agglomerations. (PostBus stop Langnau a.A., Schwerzi-Wildpark). 

Discover the woods’ many uses and secrets along the adventure path leading from the visitor’s centre by Sihlwald, Bahnhof. A woods-xylophone reveals the age of trees, and you can communicate with the wooden giants through a so-called tree-telephone. 

Boardwalk type catwalks over the stealthy waters invite you to ponder over the natural beauty that surrounds you –and a particular park highlight is presented in this wildlife park, with prime living examples of 19 species of Switzerland’s former domestic animals. Intentions are the reintroduction and conservation breeding. (PostBus stop Langnau a.A., Schwerzi-Wildpark). 

Observe the animals almost as wild and learn interesting facts through the interactive information facilities. Over the Albis Pass, you finally arrive at Hausen am Albis (PostBus stop Hausen am Albis, Post). From here you can take the Ämtlerweg path which, in three days, takes you from Bonstetten to the Affoltern district. Discover the beautiful nature reserves here as well, along with superb monuments such as the Cistercian monastery at Kappel am Albis, and Knonau Castle. 
Additional useful information on the PostBus excursion routes and a wealth of pictures and video clips can be found at the link in the right-hand box.

data.name: Cinémathèque suisse
data.abstract: Cinémathèque suisse (Switzerland’s film archive) can be viewed as Switzerland’s museum of film. But it’s not solely concerned with Swiss films, instead everything concerning the art of filming and audio-visual media in Switzerland.
data.description:
The Cinémathèque suisse collection is made up of 70,000 film copies, 2.8 million photos and 300,000 posters – and ranks sixth according to the international association of film archives (FIAF) where the world’s most important photo archives are concerned. Besides entertaining and documentary films, the Cinémathèque Suisse collection includes archived documents from Swiss film weeks, advertising and job films, as well as amateur films. In fact, you could well say that Cinémathèque is Switzerland’s audio-visual memory bank. 

As with all other comparable institutions worldwide, Cinémathèque Suisse collects everything associated with film development in Switzerland. The collection is therefore not limited solely to productions shot within home borders, instead includes films of all origins and formats. 

Cinémathèque suisse generally organizes three film presentations in a day. These take place in the Cinématographe and Paderewski hall of the Casino de Montbenon. Special events, premiers and gala evenings are mostly held in the Capitole; Switzerland’s largest cinema hall, which the town of Lausanne makes available to Cinémathèque suisse since 2010. 

Certain presentations in connection with Cinémathèque suisse are also viewed in the cinema halls of other towns, namely Filmpodium in Zurich and the Cinéma du Grütli in Geneva.

data.name: Freiämterweg – nature and culture at any time of the year!
data.abstract: It doesn’t always have to be the Camino de Santiago; you can also go on a pilgrimage along the 192km Freiämterweg. The circular hiking trail in Freiamt in Aargau takes you past historical evidence of cultural diversity.
data.description:
Start " finish:ideal places to embark on the hike are, for example, Othmarsingen railway station (S3 Zurich-Aarau/Olten), Wohlen, Muri, Sins (S26 Aarau/Lenzburg-Rotkreuz) or Mutschellen (S17, Dietikon-Wohlen).Level of difficulty:easyFitness level:easyDistance:192kmSeason:March to OctoberFood/drink:food and drink in restaurants along the routes and paths
The Freiämterweg is a regional nature and cultural hiking trail. Freiamt is a name that dates back to the Middle Ages and a description of a part of Aargau. The area extends from Mellingen in the north via Muri down to Aargau’s southern border with the cantons of Lucerne and Zug.

Highlights include monasteries and convents, old towns, magnificently restored churches and well-preserved farmhouses. The route takes you along the banks of the Reuss and a number of streams. Small pretty villages along the way invite you to linger awhile. 

The network of paths is designed in such a way as to allow you to break them down into several stages and reach them easily by public transportation. Light brown cultural hiking path signposts are provided at all stages of the Freiämterweg.

data.name: Fondue fun at the Alpenbad
data.abstract: View of relaxation Pure relaxation in the 38° warm Bachtel spring water outside in the midst of unspoilt nature. A view of relaxation and pure pleasure à discrétion! Up to five people can be seated in an Alpine bath - whether as a family, among friends, as a club or company. In addition to regional fondue, you can choose from table grills with products from our own farm or a delicious cold meat platter.
data.description:
Pure nature and a beautiful view of Lake Zurich including the Alpine panorama - you are guaranteed an exceptional evening.

As a small but fine family business, enjoyment is at the heart of everything we do. Together with our team, we do everything we can to offer you some unforgettable moments of enjoyment during your visit, in a place where you feel comfortable and appreciated as a guest - we like people. Regionality is one of our main concerns. We heat the baths with wood from our own forest and with wood from the Bachtel region. You sit in the Bachtel spring water. Our 4 in-house springs with two 15'000lt reservoirs supply water from the Bachtel-Nagelflueh.

We get the fondue from the nearby Chäsi Girenbad, where we are the main buyers of the fondue cheese. The unique special blend delights our guests. Some of the cows move right next to the bath.

A not everyday idea for (birthday) parties, meetings with friends, company or staff events, stag parties or romantic hours for two.

price.description: CHF 195.00 basic flat rate for the alpine pool CHF 27.00 per person for the fondue (min. 2 persons)

data.name: Coal mine Käpfnach
data.abstract: Equipped with a helmet and good shoes, this is a fun trip for the whole family and a chance to find out lots of interesting facts about the history of mining.
data.description:
The mining museum located in the former coal repository provides visitors with a fascinating insight into the 100-year old mining tradition in Horgen-Käpfnach and also explains how coal is formed. There are films, display boards and exhibits of mining lamps, tool and fossils. This is followed by a 1.4 kilometer rail ride through the dark mining tunnel - a thrilling adventure for visitors of all ages!

How to get there:
S-Bahn Line 2 or 8, or by a Lake Zürich boat to Horgen, then by local bus No. 4 or No. 5 to the Käpfnach stop. It is also possible to take a ferry from Meilen to Horgen. The Museum is a 15-minute walk.

data.name: Adliswil – Felsenegg cable car
data.abstract: The Albishorn, Hochwacht, Felsenegg and Uetliberg are the four best-known viewpoints on the Albis chain and are linked by a network of walking and hiking trails.
data.description:
The Felsenegg can be reached from Adliswil in the Sihl valley, just outside Zurich, with the only public cable car in the canton of Zurich – part of the Zurich transport network. It sweeps you up to 803 metres above sea level in just five minutes. When you arrive on the Felsenegg, you will find breathtaking views, a tempting restaurant and countless walking trails.

To the south you can walk to the Albis Pass, to the north take the planet trail (Planetenweg) from Pluto via Neptune, Saturn and Earth to the Sun on the Uetliberg (each metre of the trail represents 1 million kilometres in the solar system).

Altitude: 805 metres 
How to get there: 
S4 suburban train from Zurich main station to Adliswil, 10-minute walk (slightly uphill) to the valley station, cable car to the Felsenegg 
Views: Across the city of Zurich, to the Uetliberg, across Lake Zurich to the Säntis, Speer and Glärnisch; on the ridge walk, to Central Switzerland with the Rigi and Titlis 
Attractions: Felsenegg/Albis Nordic Walking Park (six trails at three levels of difficulty), planetary path to the Uetliberg 
Food and drink: Gasthaus Felsenegg inn, Fondue evening by the 120-year-old tiled stove 
Accommodation: Hotel Uto Kulm on the Uetliberg and at the Albis Pass 
Groups: Seating for 90 in the restaurant, seating for 150 on the terrace, various meeting rooms 
Winter: Operates all year round, winter hikes 
Special comments: The Felsenegg cable car is part of the Zurich fare network, included in GA travelcard 
Fully included in Swiss Travel Pass/GA travelcard. Buy your Swiss Travel System ticket [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]

DAY TRIPS TO THE MOUNTAINS
Buy your return rail and mountain ascent tickets now

Timetable and tickets [https://www.sbb.ch/de/kaufen/pages/fahrplan/fahrplan.xhtml?&nach=Felsenegg]

data.name: Landquart Fashion Outlet

Set against the picturesque backdrop of the Graubünden mountains, the Landquart Fashion Outlet awaits you. Just 60 minutes from Zurich, 90 minutes from Lucerne or 10 minutes from Chur.

More than 80 stores offer fashion, accessories, home and lifestyle products and a fascinating selection of outdoor and sports equipment.

Take a stroll around the chalet-style shopping village, enjoy the magical atmosphere and let yourself be spoiled by the fine cuisine served at the “Margaux” restaurant. 

Open 363 days each year from 10:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. Also open on Sundays.

 * Enjoy the snacks or fine food and drink in the restaurants or from the mobile food vendors.
 * Combine your shopping trip with a tour of the wineries of the Bündner Herrschaft and/or a wine tasting. For more information call +41 81 300 02 22.

data.name: Vocational Training Centre Baden
data.abstract: Monumental and as austere as an archaic temple, the new vocational school is located at the entrance to Baden. Its architecture reveals very little of the building’s purpose to those passing by.
data.description: In its formal abstraction, the school could also be an office, laboratory or even a residential building. The architectural expression is coloured by the summation of concrete columns, whose interstices are filled in with glass. The classrooms are – contrary to popular convention – not positioned on the facade but are concentrated at the core. It opens up in the middle like a colonnade over the full length of the building along the windows. Architects: Burkard Meyer Architekten BSA, Baden (2006) Photographer: Roger Frei, Zurich

Training and development for its employees is particularly important to the company. This beautiful craft has been its passion for four generations.

data.name: “Quality of life” journey of discovery
data.abstract: Everyone is searching for quality of life – be surprised by Baden, which offers you this at every turn, at work and in everyday life.
data.description:
Embark on a new journey of discovery in the only city wellness destination of the Zurich tourism region that can be experienced with all your senses. Find out exciting facts about the power of Baden’s impressive forest, the influence of the tranquillity and colours of the well-maintained park of Villa Boveri, the importance of the softly murmuring River Limmat, and the long journey that Switzerland’s most mineral-rich thermal water makes before it reaches Baden.
Experience at first hand the essence of the zest for life that Baden offers, and feel the full effect it has on your own personal well-being at work and in everyday life, while finding inspiration for your own individual resources. 
The experience tour is offered as a public tour and as a private tour for groups. [https://www.baden.ch/en/recreational-activities/city-tours.html/1332]

More information [https://www.baden.ch/en/cultural-promotion.html/1838]

data.name: Historical Points
data.abstract: The city that began as a monastery. Lucerne traces its roots directly to St.Leodegar monastery, a small 8th century Benedictine cloister. Over the centuries a community grew along the Reuss River from the monastery to a nearby settlement. Historians regard Lucerne’s birth date to be 1178, when the parish was officially transferred from the monastery to the city. Middle Age fortifications, such as the famous Chapel Bridge, are timeless witnesses of the city’s rapid growth.
data.description:
HIGHLIGHTS IN LUZERN.
Religious sites [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/interests/excursions/religious-sites.html?start=26]
Overnight at a monestary [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/accommodation/other_types/extraordinary-hotels-in-switzerland/overnights-in-a-monastery.html]
Christmas Markets [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/event_calendar/event_results.cfm?f2=stxmas] 
NICHOLAS VON FLÜE
St. Nicholas of Flüe lived in the 15th century at a quiet river gorge near Lucerne. Commonly called “Brother Klaus,” he began his life as a successful farmer, town councilor and husband. But at 50 Nicholas felt God’s pull toward a life of seclusion. With the support of his wife and 10 children, Brother Klaus became a hermit and lived out his remaining years as a spiritual counselor and skillful arbitrator of political disputes. He was instrumental in arbitrating several treaties and political disputes, earning a reputation as a peacemaker and the role of Switzerland’s patron saint, being respected by Catholics and Protestants alike. Several sites related to his life are active pilgrimage sites, including his home and retreat in Ranft George near Flüeli-Ranft and his grave in Sachseln. 

ABBEY OF EINSIEDELN
In 828 Meinrad, a Ben edictine monk from Lake Constance, withdrew as a hermit to a secluded mountain valley east of Lucerne. There, Meinrad lived and prayed in solitude until 861, when he was killed by bandits. St.Meinrad’s retreat forms the core of the monastery at Einsiedeln, located only 1 hour east of Lucerne. Set on the location of St.Meinrad’s retreat, Einsiedeln (which means “hermitage”) has attracted the devout for over 1,000 years. Eberhart became the first abbot of the community under Benedictine rule in the 10th century. Pilgrimage to the monastery began no later than the 14th century, when the monastery acquired the Black Madonna, an icon so named for the black candle smoke that colors her skin and the infant Jesus. The Black Madonna is usually clothed in elaborate attire and resides in the Lady Chapel, which rests over the site of St.Meinrad’s cell. The chapel in turn resides within the nave of the baroque Abbey Church. Huldrych Zwingli, leader of the Swiss Reformation, served briefly as a priest at Einsiedeln but moved to Zürich where he persuaded thousands to join the Protestant Reformation.

JESUIT CHURCH
The Jesuit Church is the first large sacral Baroque building in Switzerland and was constructed in 1666 by Father Christoph Vogler for the Jesuits. The vault was redecorated in the mid-18th century. The original vestments of Brother Klaus, are stored in the inner chapel.
THE INTERNATIONAL MUSEUM OF THE REFORMATION
This museum is a must-see for religious visitors that come to Geneva, Switzerland. It begins with an emphasis on the Bible and includes some of the oldest French and English Bibles. Unique objects, manuscripts, rare books, engravings and paintings illustrate the close ties of Geneva and John Calvin to the Reformation.
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/interests/excursions/religious-sites/musee-international-de-la-reforme-international-museum-of-the-reformation-genf.html]
OVERNIGHT IN A MONASTERY
Experience how it is to live in a monastery and overnight in one of the various abbeys and monasteries in Switzerland that offer simple accommodation. Some even offer their own mountain hut refuge to rent, like the convent of St.John in Muestair
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/accommodation/other_types/extraordinary-hotels-in-switzerland/overnights-in-a-monastery.html?all]
THE PILGRIMAGE WAY OF ST. JAMES ALONG SWITZERLAND’S BREATHTAKING MOUNTAIN SCENERY.
Walk or cycle on St. James' footsteps, following his ways through the breathtaking mountain scenery of Switzerland to Santiago de Compostela. Take your time to visit some of the traditional pilgrims' stations.
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/home/summervacations/excursion-summer/summer-mountain-tips/the-way-itself-is-the-goal.html]
CHRISTMAS MARKETS.
The Christmas season will soon be here again.. as well as the traditional Christmas markets in Switzerland. Montreux is home to the largest one, Bremgarten (Aargau) to one of the biggest ones in terms of vendors. The highest one can be visited on Mt. Pilatus. Others can be found in Huttwil (Bern), Zürich or Basel. 
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/service-updates/events.html?strubrik=2161]

data.name: Bier Factory Rapperswil AG, Rapperswil
data.abstract: Bier Factory Rapperswil AG from Rapperswil
data.description:
The craft beer brewery Bier Factory opened its doors many years ago and is one of the oldest craft beer breweries in Switzerland. Over the years this small brewery has gained a lot of respect from the local craft beer scene, due to their continuous innovation and production of high quality beer. All beers are hand brewed, unfiltered and mostly top-fermented. Bier Factory produce several American style beers (IPA, Swiss Pale Ale, Stout, Craft Lager….) as well as seasonal specials such as Fondue Bier, Pumpkin Ale or beer containing Chocolate and Marshmallows.

You can buy freshly brewed beer straight from the brewery. Bier Factory also offers activities for groups such as beer tasting or brewery tours. Come by and check out the brewery and enjoy a few beers. Located only 6 minutes’ walk from Jona train station. 35 minutes by train from Zurich Main Station.

Visitors are always welcome.

data.name: Therme Zurzach
data.abstract: Wellness in Switzerland’s largest thermal baths. The varied experiences on offer at Therme Zurzach invite visitors to take a moment and relax.
data.description:
The history of Bad Zurzach [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/bad-zurzach/]as a spa resort began in 1914, when hot spring water was discovered by chance while drilling for salt. This has been bubbling up to the surface from a depth of around 400 metres since 1955.

Today, Therme Zurzach [https://www.thermezurzach.ch/]is one of the largest thermal spa resorts in Switzerland. The soothing warmth and precious minerals from the rocks of the Zurzach sodium sulphate spring have a relaxing and vitalising effect.

This varied spa landscape is the perfect place to leave your day-to-day life behind you. In the outdoor area, you can enjoy the wonderfully warm thermal water in four pools even in the depths of winter. Head to the unheated natural swimming pool in the spa’s gardens to cool off. In the evening, underwater lights create a special ambience in the wellness pool. Choose between four pools in the indoor area of the spa for a diverse experience. These include the intensive brine bath that promises deep relaxation thanks to the high salt content, cave-like ambience and underwater music.

Therapeutic bathing can be supplemented with the stimulating effect of heat from the “textile” saunas, in which bathing suits can be worn, and the crystal steam bath. The relaxing and rejuvenating experiences are rounded off by indoor and outdoor zones for relaxation and lounging, surrounded by beautiful parkland, a restaurant and two bars.

In the exclusive, textile-free bore rig sauna landscape – which is based on the history of salt drilling in Bad Zurzach – several saunas, steam baths and a cold water pool as well as an elegant bar and lounge area provide an unforgettable boost to wellbeing.

Younger guests will enjoy the indoor Papa Moll children’s paddling pool and the water playground outside.

Arrival
Bad Zurzach train station is just a few minutes’ walk from the thermal baths (50 minutes from Zurich, 1 hour 30 minutes from Bern). The thermal bath also has its own bus stop served by local buses: “Bad Zurzach, Therme”. To the timetable [https://www.sbb.ch/de]
Paid parking is also available for those making the journey by car.

data.name: Horse and carriage rides in Raten
data.abstract: Horse and carriage rides in Raten are a romantic and pleasurable experience both in summer and winter.
data.description: Raten is located high above Oberägeri, just half an hour from Zurich, and it’s here that you can partake in scenic horse and carriage rides through the countryside. Winter is the time to book a romantic sleigh ride warmly tucked under a blanket, with a tasty fondue at the Restaurant Raten to complete an idyllic outing.

data.name: Old recipes from Möhlin
data.description: Hostess Manuela Eiermann’s roots are in Zurich and the Ticino, but she and her family settled in Möhlin, Canton Aargau. Manuela collected and reinterpreted old recipes from the village and published a cookbook. Dinner is served with white wine from her vineyard. Some of the vines are close to 140 years old.

price.description: CHF 96.00 incl. wine CHF 46.00 per child

data.name: Hotel Rigi Kulm
data.abstract: The Hotel Rigi Kulm has been welcoming guests for almost 200 years.
data.description:
Remarkable for its unique location on the summit of the queen of the peaks, this hotel has 70 beds for hikers, individualists, walkers and nature-lovers. It is also the perfect place for a short break. Having been extensively renovated, the hotel is to reopen at the end of April 2007.INFORMATION

Sunset:
For nearly 200 years all guests have been enchanted by the sunset and sunrise rising over Mt. Rigi. Guests, who don’t stay overnight on the Rigi, can ride the cogwheel train up to Vitznau during the summer months.

By public transport:
From Lucerne to Goldau or Küssnacht and then by local bus to Weggis or Vitznau
From Zürich Airport / Main Station to Lucerne and then by boat to Weggis / Vitznau, or from Zürich Airport / Main Station to Goldau.

By car:
From Berne: take the A1 / A2 motorway, from Basel the A2, from Zürich the A4, all of them in the direction of the Gotthard. Exit: Küssnacht (for Vitznau / Weggis) or Goldau (for Goldau) 

By boat:
 * From Lucerne Bahnhofplatz to Weggis or Vitznau
 * By train to Arth and then by local bus to Goldau


Mt. Rigi is serviced by two railways and a cable car and hence is easy to reach:
 * cog railway Vitznau - Rigi Kulm
 * cog railway Goldau - Rigi Kulm
 * cable car Weggis - Rigi Kaltbad

data.name: Seerenbach Falls and the Rin Spring
data.abstract: A forest trail leads from Betlis village to a vantage point, opening up a vista to a gigantic water spectacle. The Seerenbach thunders over the vertical cliff face on the northern shore of Lake Walen, cascading 585 m in a series of stages down to Betlis to join the waters of the Rin Spring.
data.description:
It is impressive: a waterjet spews forth from the rock 305 meters high. The water of the Rinquelle originates in a huge cave system deep in the Churfirsten. Divers have been investigating it since the beginning of the 20th century. It is evident that there is a 3-km-long canal that leads somewhere deep into the bowels of the mountain. What happens then, however, is still a mystery. 

How to get there: 
Drive or take public transportation from Zürich via Ziegelbrücke near Betlis on Lake Walen (boat from Weesen).

data.name: The Angelone family in Toggenburg
data.abstract: The ultimate family adventure! The Toggenburg region is brimming with family fun and adventure. The Angelones hiked, rested and even trekked through the treetops in the Toggenburg region.
data.description:
The Angelones tested the family friendliness of Toggenburg and the surrounding area from 14 to 16 June 2019. They stayed at the Hotel Stump’s Alpenrose [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/accommodations/stumps-alpenrose/]. 

Here, they tell us what they got up to in the Toggenburg region: 

“Our visit to Toggenburg has been packed with unforgettable family adventures. The region has so much to offer, from donkey hikes and the Sound Trail through to downhill monster bike trails and the exhilarating Baumwipfelpfad treetop adventure path [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/treetop-path-neckertal/]! 
Wildhaus is a perfect base for active and adventurous family holidays. Just an hour’s drive from Zurich, it transports you to another world for the weekend. Nestled between the mighty Säntis mountain and the seven Churfirsten peaks, this beautiful region is the perfect place to recharge your batteries with its stunning scenery and diverse array of cultures and customs.”

To read the full blog entry about their trip, click here [https://www.dieangelones.ch/wildhaus-im-toggenburg-perfekter-ausgangsort-fuer-familienferien/].

data.name: Toggenburger Höhenweg
data.abstract: The Toggenburger Höhenweg presents hikers with one of the most beautiful but also one of the most challenging hiking routes in the St. Gallen countryside. Breathtaking and incomparable views constantly draw your gaze down into the lush green Thurtal valley.
data.description:
Start of tour:Wildhaus End of tour:Will SG Number of stages:6Length:87 km Difficulty:mediumCondition:difficult Difference in altitude:↑ 4600 m
↓ 5100 m 
The scenic Toggenburger Höhenweg runs parallel to the Thurweg. Unlike the Thurweg, which follows alongside the River Thur on the valley floor, the Höhenweg leads at a height along the south/west side of the Toggenburg valley. Starting point is Wildhaus, birthplace of reformer Huldrych Zwingli and home of four-times Olympic champion Simon Ammann (Unterwasser). 

The Höhenweg repeatedly has links into the valley, to typical Toggenburg villages with public transport connections. Simple, hospitable mountain huts make it possible to stay overnight at a lofty height. This is rewarding mainly because of the wonderful views of the Churfirsten mountains at an early or late hour. En route, you'll be constantly enthralled by the extensive views over the Glarus Alps and the Walensee and Zürichsee lakes into Toggenburg as far as the Bodensee (Lake Constance). 

Towards its end, the Höhenweg leaves the rather challenging mountain trail and finishes amidst gently rolling hills in the town of Wil, known as the gateway to Toggenburg.

data.name: Steam Ahead on 15 Scheduled Lake Steamers
data.abstract: Enjoy a trip on any of the 15 steam boats sailing on 8 Swiss lakes.
data.description: Switzerland is not only a country of mountains but also of lakes. Lakes means that one should have boats on them, preferably steamers. This is the case on on 8 Swiss lakes which has 16 lake steamers. Each one is a historic boat, which was restored for many million Swiss francs. Lake Luzern has the most of these behemoths (5 boats) which fascinate children as much as adults. Lake Geneva has 4 of these proud examples of the 19th century. Other wonderful examples are the Lötschberg on Lake Brienz, and the Blümlisalp on Lake Thun. A smaller specimen, the Greif, sails on Lake Zurich. Steam Ahoy!

data.name: Alpstein Paragliding
data.abstract: Ebenalp, Kronberg, Churfirsten, Pizol, Malbun
data.description:
Typically, you can either fly from Walenstadt mountain, along the Churfirsten up to Ländle, or launch from the foot of mount Säntis at Wasserauen. Flights from the Fronalpstock or near the town of Schänis or from the Kleine Scheidegg pass are just as good. For flying connoisseurs, the flight zone stretches from the Principality of Liechtenstein almost up to Lake Zurich and from Lake Walen rght up to Lake Constance. – A passenger flight in the Alpstein mountain ranges is and will always remain an unforgettable experience.

data.name: By foot to Heidi’s mountain hut
data.abstract: The adventures of Heidi, the orphan girl, are known the world over. Not least through the eponymous film from 1952. One of the original locations is above St. Moritz and can be visited at all times.
data.description:
Heidi. We owe it to the Zürich author Johanna Spyri that the name became synonymous with a down-to-earth Swiss girl. It was 140 years ago that the parson’s daughter from Zürich wrote the adventures of the cheerful orphan girl. Today the work is one of the world’s most popular children’s books. 

That Heide became so widely known is also due to the marvelous film from 1952. The legendary Heinrich Gretler as Alpöhi (Alpine grandfather) remains unforgettable. If you want to visit his cabin, travel to St. Moritz and hike from there to the Salastrains area. At the end of your hike you can sit on the small wooden bench in front of the hut. Or lower your head and glance into the dark interior of the simple wooden house.

data.name: Liquid pleasure
data.abstract: The caress of the wine. “It’s a pity that you cannot caress the wines,” said the satirist Kurt Tucholsky. He was a great wine lover, as so many Swiss are. It’s a great pleasure to stroll through a vineyard when the vines are budding, or when the grapes are ripening; or to visit winemakers and taste their proudest creations. The largest winegrowing areas are in Western Switzerland, on the shores of Lakes Geneva, Neuchâtel, Biel and Murten, and along the valley of the Rhone in the Valais, Switzerland’s most richly varied winegrowing canton. The Valais is home to the highest commercial vineyards in Europe, but some excellent wines flourish in Eastern Switzerland and Graubünden as well. You may not be able to caress Swiss wines, but they will certainly caress your palate.
data.description:
THE MOST SCENIC: LAKE GENEVA REGION
The setting of the Lavaux vineyards above Lake Geneva is quite simply spectacular. You can taste their wines in the Caveau des Vignerons in Lutry. www.vins-vaudois.com [http://www.vins-vaudois.com] 

THE MOST OF ALL: VALAIS
The Valais is a canton of superlatives: the highest vineyards in Europe (Visperterminen), the highest dry-stone walls in the world (near Sion), and a wine-tasting cellar with 500 local wines (Château de Villa, Sierre). www.vinsduvalais.ch [http://www.vinsduvalais.ch] 

THE MOST SOUTHERN: TICINO
You can explore the vineyards of Ticino in half a day, following the wine trail between Gudo and Biasca – and stop at welcoming grotti (traditional inns) along the way. www.ticino-tourism.ch [http://www.ticino-tourism.ch] 

THE MOST WELCOMING: BÜNDNER HERRSCHAFT
Maienfeld is not only the home of Heidi, but also the home of some of the country’s finest wines. Every weekend from April to November, a different winemaker opens its doors to the public, starting at 11am. www.buendnerweine.ch [http://www.buendnerweine.ch]
ASTONISHING VARIETY, SURPRISING SPECIALITIES
More than 50 grape varieties are cultivated in Switzerland, tempting wine lovers to explore and discover them. To the Valais, to taste the Petite Arvine and Amigne (white), the Humagne rouge and Cornalin (red); to the shores of Lake Geneva, for the rare red Petit Robert; to Lake Zürich, for the white Räuschling; or to the Bündner Herrschaft, where – alongside a magnificent Pinot noir – the age-old Completer grows. You are sure to come across the Chasselas, the main grape of Western Switzerland, as well as the Merlot of Ticino, and maybe even the new Swiss varieties, Garanoir and Diolinoir.

data.name: Everyone loves chocolate
data.abstract: “Nine out of ten people like chocolate. The tenth is lying.” (Graffiti scrawled on a wall ). Every Swiss child would agree: their favourite afternoon snack has always been bread and chocolate. During the more than 400 years since Columbus became the first European to see cocoa beans, Switzerland has come to the forefront of chocolate manufacturing worldwide. Swiss chocolatiers have created such delights as truffles, pralines, cakes, and mousses (enough to make a Swiss child forget about the bread ) … Swiss chocolate is great on its own, or with an espresso, a sweet wine, whisky or a Cognac, and on any conceivable occasion. For more on the subject, see: www.chocosuisse.ch
data.description:
THE SWISS CHOCOLATE TRAIN
Travel first-class in a genuine 19th century Belle Époque Pullman car from Montreux through an idyllic landscape, and visit a cheese dairy, a castle, and the Cailler-Nestlé factory in Broc, all on the Swiss Chocolate Train, operated by Golden- Pass Services. Runs June to October. More Information... [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/reisen/transport/bahnreisen-zugfahren-panoramastrecken/swiss-chocolate-train.html] 

CHOCOLATE HEAVEN
There’s no need for false modesty: Swiss chocolatiers are the best in the world. Every town and city in Switzerland has its favourite practitioner of the art, Teuscher [http://www.teuscher.com] on Bahnhofstrasse in Zürich, for example, for champagne truffles, or Blondel [https://blondel.ch/fr/] in Lausanne’s Old Town, with 120 different creations. 

BEHIND THE SCENES
Chocosuisse is an association of 18 different chocolate makers, large and small, some of which are open to visits by the public. Visitors can learn how chocolate is produced from an audiovisual presentation, follow a tour, have a tasting, and buy chocolate to take away from the factory shop. Chocolate makers include:

 * Cailler-Nestlé [https://www.cailler.ch/en/maison-cailler] in Broc/FR (open April-October)
 * Alprose [http://www.alprose.ch] in Caslano-Lugano/TI (daily)
 * Maestrani [https://www.chocolarium.ch/fr/] in Flawil/SG (Monday- Saturday)
 * Aeschbach Chocolatier [https://aeschbach-chocolatier.ch/en/choco-events/] in Root/LU (open Monday - Sunday, online registration possible)
 * Chocolat Frey [https://www.chocolatfrey.ch/centre-visiteurs/page-d-accueil] in Buchs/AG (groups, by appointment only)
 * Läderach [http://www.schoggi-erlebnis.ch/en/] in Bilten, Ennenda, Vevey and Zurich.


Swiss Chocolate Adventure 
The Swiss Chocolate Adventure is a new theme world within the Swiss Muesum of Transport that allows the visitor to learn interesting facts about the discovery, origin, production and transport of chocolate. 
Mehr Informationen hier [https://www.verkehrshaus.ch/fr/visiter/swiss-chocolate-adventure.html]

data.name: Irchel Tower
data.abstract: The Irchel Tower offers you a wonderful view across the entire wine country up to the Säntis and across the Flaach Valley up to Germany.
data.description: The 28-meter-high tower built in 1983 replaces an earlier tower. The Irchel Tower was in the past a bone of contention. In the 1970s, Canton Zurich’s power plants agreed to finance the new structure, provided a new antenna for the planned radio network was installed atop the tower. About 50 steps lead to the top of the Irchel Tower. This vantage point has a rest area and is well-suited for families. Hiking trails from various directions make the tower accessible.

data.name: Excursion: Alttäufergemeinde Emmental, Mennoniten (Langnau Mennonite Church)
data.abstract: The Langnau Mennonite Church, a small congregation in the nearby town of Langnau, lies about 30 minutes by train from Bern.
data.description: The church traces its roots to the early Anabaptist founders in Zürich, and is one of several centuries-old congregations still active in the Bern area.

data.name: Stadthaus (Town Hall)
data.abstract: The municipal administration’s proud main building today is comprised of four formerly separate buildings: the chancellery, armoury, town hall and town house.
data.description:
In the 18th century, the three Protestant Estates of Zurich, Berne and Glarus exchanged this building for their chancellery building on the Rathausgasse and commissioned architect Franz Anton Schwarz from Bremgarten to convert it into a new local records office. During the period of the revolution, the building reverted temporarily into private hands, but since 1892 it has been owned by the municipality and is the seat of the municipal government. It was renovated on the outside in 1918, 1969/70 and in 2013. In 1997/98 the interior was modernised by Baden architects Zulauf und Schmidlin. The Stadthaus has been declared a Swiss listed building.

On the second floor is the meeting room of the old Confederation, with a polychrome ceiling with beams, and with copies of the glass panels painted by the Zürich glass painter Lukas Zeiner, donated by ten towns in 1500 and sold in 1812.

data.name: Voralpen-Express
data.abstract: The gentle side of Switzerland: It’s not all 4000-metre mountains and deep ravines. On the Voralpen-Express, visitors discover a different kind of Switzerland – undulating hills, picturesque villages and lovely orchards.
data.description:
Voralpen-Express is the most appealing way to travel between Eastern and Central Switzerland. Starting from Eastern Switzerland’s urban centre of St. Gallen, whose Abbey district is a UNESCO world heritage site, the train traverses the 99 metre high Sitter viaduct and the rolling landscape of “Toggenburg”. Passing by Rapperswil and the impressive upland moor near Rothenthurm, the journey ends after a little over two hours in historic Lucerne on the shores of Lake Lucerne.
FACTS
Route: St. Gallen – Wattwil – Rapperswil – Arth Goldau – Luzern
Distance: 125 km 
Duration: 2 h 18 min
EXCURSION TIPS
St. Gallen [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/destinations/st-gallen/] and surrounding area
 * Abbey district and Abbey library
 * Säntis – one of the most breathtaking panoramas of Switzerland at 2505 m a.s.l. 
 * Appenzell region – tradition is important between Bodensee and Säntis 

Rapperswil [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/destinations/rapperswil-jona/] and surrounding area
 * Rapperswil castle
 * Lake Zurich Navigation – 2 steamboats and 12 motor boats regularly navigate Lake Zurich

Lucerne [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/destinations/lucerne/]
 * Lion’s Monument – in memorial of Swiss citizens who died in 1792 during the French Revolution 
 * Lake Lucerne boat tours
 * Landscape and Animal Park Goldau – refuge for stags, wolves, lynxes and other wild animals 

FOOD & BEVERAGES
Each train has a bistro coach with catering services.TIMETABLE
All connections here [http://www.sbb.ch/en/home.html]TICKET
This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]

OFFERS
Book here [https://switzerlandtravelcentre.com/en/holidays/train-journeys/voralpen-express]RESERVATIONS
No seat reservation possible – free seating.
